Xiamen University Shenzhen Guangdong 518057 China Shenzhen Research Institute of Xiamen University, Shenzhen 518057, Guangdong, China * Corresponding author Electrochemical overall water splitting (OWS) has drawn much research fascination as a promising technology for energy conversion to produce clean hydrogen fuel as sustainable chemical resources. However, half reaction of the water splitting reaction, which is oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the main challenge due to the sluggish kinetics and large thermodynamic barrier. Porous-based materials can markedly enhance the accessibility of active sites, increase specific surface area and optimize the adsorption/desorption of reactants. The enhanced activity arising from the porous materials is attributed to the increase in active sites and improved mass transfer. Herein, the recent research advances made in porous electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and OWS are reviewed. This review focuses on the recent advancements in the synthesis strategies, incorporated with the unique roles of porous structure in electrocatalysts are discussed. For boosting the activity, various emerging modification strategies on porous electrocatalysts, covering structure engineering, phase engineering, defect engineering and strain engineering are presented. This review emphasizes on the synthesis methods, how porous materials improve the performance, mechanistic understanding, integrated experiments, theoretical studies in water splitting, advanced modification strategies and proposed synthesis processes. Specially, the structural-activity relationship gives insights into designing and modifying the porous-based materials with unique properties. Finally, the current science challenges and direction for the future development of porous electrocatalysts are highlighted. Graphical Abstract The synthesis methods for the preparation of porous electrocatalysts and the emerging modification strategies in porous materials are briefly introduced. The structural-activity relationship for electrocatalytic HER, OER and OWS is exemplified. Keywords Porous materials Electrocatalysis Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Water splitting 1 Introduction Owing to the rapid development of industrialization and the rapid growth of the population, it is projected that the energy demand will be rising rapidly where the primary energy grew by 31 EJ in 2021, which was 1.3% above 2019, the largest increase in history, as reported by BP statistics [1,2]. The gradual depletion of the world's major energy non-renewable sources such as petrol, natural gas and coal, is an issue that needs to be solved. Over-dependency on non-renewable energy sources causes a series of air pollution, energy shortage and global warming. The increasing challenges in energy demands and environmental issues facilitate the rapid development of renewable and clean fuels, aiming to replace conventional energy sources. Molecular hydrogen (H2) is one of the most promising fuel sources, as it is one of the zero-carbon-contained fuels. H2 acts as an excellent energy carrier as pollution-free water will be the only by-product after combustion and its gravimetric energy density is the highest (142 MJ kg−1), three times higher than conventional fossil fuels such as gasoline [3–5]. However, conventionally most of the production route for H2 is by steam reforming of fossil fuels. Steam reforming production route has a low conversion rate and it generates CO2 and forms coke during the reaction. Moreover, this technology requires high temperature and pressure and both the catalyst and people's health are endangered by residual CO intermediates produced from incomplete combustion [6–8]. To date, a clean and high-efficiency route for the generation of H2 is the key element that aroused the attention of researchers in striving towards the sustainable development goal listed by the United Nations. Electrochemical water splitting is one of the emerging environment-friendly technologies for producing hydrogen, which includes hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). This method has been considered one of the clean strategies to replace fossil fuels because the combustion of H2 produces energy and regenerates H2O at the same time, thereby building a carbon-free hydrogen circular economy. This is because water is acting as the sole starting molecule and by-product for the whole process. Electrocatalytic water-splitting technology that employs electrocatalysts has come to light as an intriguing and promising strategy for the splitting of water to produce green energy and H2 as a fuel source since the first discovery of the electrolysis reported in 1789 [9,10]. The overall reaction of water splitting can be divided into two half-cell reactions, namely HER and OER. Considering that the typical OER and HER through water splitting are difficult attributed to the sluggish kinetics of the electron transport. During the electrochemical process (Fig. 1(a) ), energy input is required to overcome the energy barrier for the water-splitting process, which is known as the overpotential (η). Typically, water electrolyzer cells operate at a voltage of 1.8–2.0 V, which is higher than the theoretical value (~1.23 V) [6,11]. This is one of the major limitations which significantly restricted the industrialization of electrocatalytic water splitting applications. In the light of this, tremendous efforts have been devoted to pursuing discoveries in the world of materials science and engineering, to design suitable catalysts, which are stable and able to minimize the activation energy barrier for efficient H2 and O2 productions. To date, the state-of-the-art HER and OER electrocatalysts are noble metal-based, such as Pt-based materials for HER and IrO2/RuO2-based catalysts for OER, respectively, but the high cost and scarcity have hindered their widespread use [12,13]. Therefore, in the last decades, enormous research attempts have been dedicated to developing alternatives, which are low-cost and highly efficient in the interconversion of chemical and electrical energy [14–17]. Transition metal-based materials, such as metal oxides [18,19], hydroxides [20], sulfides [21], carbides [22], phosphides [23] and nitrides [24] have been widely investigated. Stemming from the distinctive structural features, rich active sites, earth-abundant, synergy effect between transition metal ions, strong corrosion-resistance in alkaline media, and easily tuned electronic properties and components have triggered researchers’ interest [6,25]. Recently, a variety of porous materials have emerged as promising alternative nanomaterials for next-generation electrocatalysts [26–28]. An illustration of the porous materials was shown in Fig. 1(b). Owing to the distinctive physical and chemical properties of porous materials dissimilar from bulk materials, which are advantageous to be widely applied in electrocatalysis, where the heterogeneous process happens on the interfaces of the materials. Therefore, this has enabled them to be versatile in electrocatalysis to offer more active sites, enhancing electric conductivity and lower mass transfer resistance during electrocatalysis [29–31]. Typically, the porous structure can be divided into various categories based on the pore sizes, such as microporous, mesoporous and macroporous materials [32]. The porous materials possess remarkable performances, as they usually demonstrate a unique porous hierarchy with structure and porosity ranging from micro- to macropore size. In addition, the structural uniqueness enabled the materials to have multilevel porosity, larger accessible spaces as well as the interconnection between different levels of porosities, thereby enhancing the electrolyte transport and mass diffusion, which is important in improving their electrocatalytic performance. Furthermore, the perfect combination of the porous structure and metal merits has attracted significant interest from researchers due to their structural advantages in electrochemical energy conversion processes [32–34]. In addition, the past few years have witnessed a surge of interest in developing porous structured metal-based nanomaterials in the electrocatalysis field (Fig. 3 ), stemming from the effective solution to eliminate aggregation and restacking in 1D and 2D electrode materials. For example, Wei et al. [35] reported porous Co3O4 nanosheets with abundant oxygen vacancies. The as-prepared catalyst displayed mesoporous nanostructures with enhanced electrolyte penetration and no aggregation occurred. For another example, Li and co-workers [36] fabricated a cracked monolayer porous 1T MoS2 nanosheets fabricated via lithium intercalation of hydrothermal synthesis aided by ultrasonication. The catalyst showed ameliorated catalytic performance, ascribing to the abundant edge sides, open porous structure, enlarged surface area and the metallic 1T phase MoS2. Besides that, the 3D porous structure can also be fabricated and implemented as the substrates, such as metal foams and conductive carbon materials.3D nanostructured electrocatalysts had also been developed into a free-standing system and directly used as the working electrodes. Liu et al. [37] fabricated a 3D self-supporting porous network NiCeO x @NiFeO x on nickel foam as substrate, with excellent stability and high current densities. Compared with bulk materials, the porous materials not only possess abundant accessible active sites and high mass transfer capability, but also exhibit other intriguing properties, such as low density and increased specific current density in water electrolysis, porous structure materials have been significantly blooming in various energy conversion applications. By virtue of the fascinating electrical conductivity and high active sites of porous structure, research interest revolving around porous structured electrocatalysts has explosively increased in the past decades (Fig. 2 ). Recently, several reviews related to porous electrocatalysts have been published. For instance, Ren et al. [38] summarized an overview of the recent development of innovation strategies for different fabrication strategies of porous non-noble-metal materials. On the other hand, Chen et al. [39] discussed active site engineering in porous electrocatalysts and its intriguing attributes in improving electrochemical reactions. Moreover, Yang's group [40] summarized on the porous based organic polymers (POPs) for electrocatalysis. Later, Adegoke et al. [41] reviewed the porous metal-oxide electrocatalytic nanomaterials on the energy application and highlighted the roles of oxygen vacancy in porous materials in achieving better electrocatalytic performance, which once again showed the soaring interest in porous materials up to date. In addition, Du et al. [28] reported on the synthesis methods and the application of porous electrocatalysts in various energy applications, while Tian's group [42] summarized the porous materials for electrocatalytic water splitting with Ru-doped. However, the relationship of the structural-performance, modification advancements on porous materials in boosting their electrocatalytic performance, advanced modification strategy and advanced characterization have not been systematically reviewed. The corresponding discussion is likely to provide innumerable insights on design and fabrication of porous materials in the future, based on both experimental and theoretical work. Herein, a timely and comprehensive review that encompasses the different synthesis methods of porous electrocatalysts and the modification strategies of electrocatalysts and their performance in HER, OER and OWS will be presented to provide guidance for future research. This review begins with the fundamentals of the reaction mechanisms, catalytic mechanisms and the general approaches for evaluating catalytic performance. Next, the typical synthesis strategies for porous electrocatalysts, which incorporates how the formation of porous structure during the synthesis, roles of porous structure in the electrocatalytic system and structural-activity relationship, are summarized. To further improve the synthesis of porous catalysts, by drawing inspiration from other applications a few synthesis strategies were proposed. Subsequently, the recent development of various modification strategies to improve catalytic performance is highlighted, and these strategies have been categorized as structure engineering, defect engineering, hybrid engineering and strain engineering. It is noteworthy that besides the common modification methods, several advanced modification methods were summarized. This review will end with a summary and some insights on the challenges and future development perspective for exploiting new porous materials for electrocatalytic systems to trigger a future breakthrough in their development and application in electrocatalytic energy conversion. 2 Fundamentals of water splitting Overall water splitting process consists of two half-cell reactions which are HER and OER which occurs almost simultaneously, occurring at the anode and cathode respectively. During the electrocatalytic water splitting process, water molecules are split into H2 and O2 gases will be produced on the reductive and the oxidative sites, respectively. However, both reactions can proceed along different pathways and in diverse media with different pH values [51]. The overall reaction for water splitting can be expressed as Eqs. (1)–(5). (1) OWS: 2H2O → 2H2 + O2 In alkaline electrolyte: (2) Cathode: 2H2O + 2e− → H2 + 2OH− (3) Anode: 4OH− → 2H2O + O2 + 4e− In acid electrolyte: (4) Cathode: 2H2O → 4H+ + O2 + 4e− (5) Anode: 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2 Theoretically, at 1 atm and 25 °C the change in free energy (ΔG) of water splitting reaction is +237.2 kJ mol−1, corresponding to the thermodynamic voltage of 1.23 V vs. RHE, where 0 V for HER and 1.23 V for OER. Particularly, due to notably more intermediates and reaction steps, OER requires significantly higher energy than HER. Nevertheless, in practice, the operation voltage for water splitting will be higher than 1.23 V. In practical, the overall cell voltage for water splitting can be described in Eq. (6) (6) V = 1.23 V + | η c | + η α + η Ω where η c is the overpotentials demanded to drive HER and η a is the overpotentials demanded to drive OER and η Ω is the potential required to compensate the internal resistance (iR) loss due to solution and contact resistance. As the additional overpotential is required to overcome the potential loss due to the intrinsic activation impediment or in other words due to the kinetic constraints in electrochemical reaction [51,52]. 2.1 Porous nanoarchitecture catalysts for overall water splitting The unique structure of porous nanoarchitecture electrocatalysts equips with appealing catalytic performances toward overall water splitting reaction. This is due to the large surface area, which can increase the density of surface-active sites, efficient transport of products, and enhanced contact of catalysts with electrolytes and reactants through the surface-active sites [6,34]. Similar to other electrocatalytic applications, overall water splitting requires catalysts with optimized exposed active sites and increased electrochemically active surface area, which improve the electrochemical performances. However, there are some limitations to porous nanoarchitecture catalysts. For instance, during some synthesis processes that involve high temperatures the solidified will melt in the pores and coarsening of pores [53]. Eventually, the surface-active sites were blocked and the rate of reaction decreased. Moreover, the tuning of the pore dimensions and pore size distributions will be a challenge to achieve the optimum structure balanced with high stability for enhanced performance during the reaction. With an in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanism, the activity trend and the design of catalysts, further improvements can be made. 2.2 HER mechanisms To further understand on overall water splitting, firstly the HER mechanism will be discussed. HER, which is also known as electrochemical water reduction, is a multi-step electrochemical reaction that generates hydrogen occurring at the cathode. Based on the Nernst equation, HER is more favorable in acidic conditions. This has been proven by experimental and theoretical studies too, where in acidic electrolyte the proton reduction to form hydrogen gas is more favorable, resulting in a relatively higher rate of reaction of HER. Basically, HER is a two-electron transfer process that happens at the surface of the cathode and this process reduces protons (in acidic media) or water molecules (in alkaline media) to H2 molecules [6,54]. Mechanistically, there are two reaction routes in the HER, which are namely Volmer-Heyrovsky and Volmer-Tafel pathways [3,55,56]. Briefly, these two mechanisms are illustrated in Eqs. (7)–(11). (a) Volmer Step (electrochemical hydrogen adsorption) (7) H3O+ + M + e− → M-H* + H2O (acidic medium) (8) H2O + M + e− → M-H* + OH− (alkaline medium) (b) Heyrovsky reaction (electrochemical desorption) (9) H+ + e− + M-H* → H2 + M (acidic medium) (10) H2O + e− + M-H* → H2 +OH− + M (alkaline medium) (c) Tafel reaction (chemical desorption) (11) 2M-H* → 2M + H2 (acidic or alkaline medium) From the equations illustrated above, during the water splitting process, the first step is the electrochemical hydrogen adsorption step, which is known as the Volmer reaction. After hydrogen adsorption, two desorption pathways are available that is Heyrovsky step for electrochemical desorption or the Tafel step for chemical desorption. In the Heyrovsky step, the adsorbed H* is a proton-coupled electron transfer process that produces H2. While in the Tafel step, the combination of two H* on the surface of the electrode forms H2. Generally, under standard condition the Tafel slope values will be 118, 39 and 29.5 mV dec−1, for Volmer, Heyrovsky and Tafel steps, respectively. The Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) readily serves as the direct descriptor for evaluation of the HER activity. It measures the capacity difference between H* adsorption and H2 desorption. When ΔG H* value is too positive, it represents a weak interaction between H* and the electrocatalyst, and the rate-limiting step will be the Volmer step. On the contrary, when ΔG H* value is highly negative, it will lead to a sluggish Heyrovsky or Tafel process due to the fact that adsorption of H* is stronger than desorption, so in this condition, either one of the processes will be the potential-limiting step [25,57]. According to Sabatier's principle, when ΔG H* is zero, the exchange current density j o, is the highest which serves as the ideal conditions. Hence, the ΔG H* value closer to zero indicates a balance between adsorption and desorption and that the HER electrocatalyst is at its optimum performance [54,58]. Gerischer and Parsons came out with the relationship of j0 and adsorption energy for HER. However, it was till 2004, that Trasatti [59] first constructed the volcano curve for HER and this supported the prediction of Gerischer and Parsons (Fig. 5(a) ). At that time, the energy of hydride formation was used to describe the adsorption energy, since there is no theoretical and experimental data for hydrogen adsorption. In 2004 with the development of computational science and theoretical calculations, Norskov's group [60,61] presented the first modern volcano plot by calculating ΔG H* via density functional theory (DFT) (Fig. 5(b)). As envisioned by Parsons the top of the “volcano plot” truly shows the zero free energy of adsorption [62]. In addition, DFT calculations can provide a close-up view of the electronic structure, particularly d states of the metal that is affecting the H* adsorption on the surface of the electrode. The d-band model is one of the useful to span the fermi level and to further display the fundamental understanding on the metal-adsorbent bond formation and trends in reactivity of the transition metal. This theory is directly related to H adsorption strength, which has been proposed by Norskov's group for the prediction of reactants and intermediates adsorption energies on the metal surface [63]. Chemical bonds were formed between the strong interaction of H electrons and the catalyst d states. In the d-band model descriptor, the interaction between the adsorbate valence state and the s and d states is shown in (Fig. 5(c)). From this image it becomes evident that the coupling of the s band gives rise to a broadening and shifting of the adsorbate states and the energy used is similar to the bond energy for all transition metals [64]. The energy in the s-band remains unchanged, hence it could be concluded that the metal d orbital electrons are the main players in chemical bonding and to determine the bond strength. However, the anti-bonding energy levels of different metals are having significant differences, due to the various interactions of the metal with H atoms and thus influence the catalytic performance. On the grounds, an optimum d-band center value is desired to attain exceptional HER electrocatalytic performance. Fig. 4 Overview of synthesis, modification strategies and electrocatalytic applications of porous electrocatalysts. 2.3 OER mechanisms OER reaction process is more complicated as compared to HER reaction. This is a process to oxidize water to generate oxygen molecules through a four-electron transfer process. The standard potential of OER is 1.23 V at pH = 0. Likewise, this reaction is pH dependent and it relies on the electrode surface structure. On the basis of electrode surface structure, it can be divided into two types: flat surface electrode and 3D electrode. Different types of surface structures alter the way of electrolyte penetrates and affect the catalysts involved in the reaction [66,67]. OER proceeds in the following steps Eqs.(12)–(19): In acidic medium: (12) 2H2O → OH* + H2O + H+ + e− (13) OH* + H2O → OOH* + H+ + e− (14) O* + H2O → OOH* + H+ + e− (15) OOH* → O2 + H* +e− In alkaline medium: (16) 4OH− → OH* + 3OH− + e− (17) OH* + 3OH− → O* + 2OH− + H2O + e− (18) O* + 2OH− + H2O → OOH* + OH− + H2O + e− (19) OOH* + OH− +H2O → O2 + 2H2O +e− OER process can be described as shown; in an acidic medium, H2O molecule loses electrons to generate O2 and H+, while in an alkaline medium OH− loses electrons to generate O2 and H2O. In the OER reaction, various intermediates will be formed including OH*, OOH* and O* in both acidic and alkaline media. These multi-step reactions (4 steps) cause the accumulation of energy barrier at each step, making OER kinetics very sluggish and thus resulting in a large overpotential to be overcome. Therefore, to overcome the energy barrier, an electrocatalyst with low overpotential is strongly desired. Among the 4 steps, the step with the highest energy barrier is the rate-limiting step. Herein a scale relationship exists between the energies of each step [55,67,68]. Through theoretical calculation for the OER process, a scaling relation between OH* and OOH* intermediates was discovered, leading to the formation of volcano plot. The binding energy difference of 1.23 eV plays a role in realizing an overpotential of zero for the reaction [69]. At the atomic level, there is a need to stabilize the OOH* concerning OH* to optimize the performance. To gain a deeper understanding of OER mechanisms, previous theoretical calculations have been estimated. Similar to the HER rate expression, OER when examined as a function of specific intermediates exhibits a volcano-shaped plot [70]. As illustrated in (Fig. 6(c) ), RuO2 is at the peak of the plot, suggesting the significant performance of Ru-based catalyst in catalyzing OER reaction, which is consistent with previous experimental results [71]. Based on the volcano plot, it illustrates that by tuning the binding energies for intermediates an optimal catalytic activity can be attained. 2.4 Evaluation criteria for water splitting performance 2.4.1 Overpotential Among all the parameters to evaluate water splitting performance, overpotential (h), is one of the most important factors to evaluate the performance of electrocatalysts. Theoretically, overpotential is defined as the difference between the actual potential and thermodynamic value at a specific current density (Eq. 20) [72]. As mentioned above, the theoretical potentials for HER and OER are 0V and 1.23V respectively. However, in practice due to the sluggish kinetics of HER and OER processes, usually a higher applied potential is needed to overcome the intrinsic active energy barrier during the catalytic process. (20) η = E applied – E 0 – iR where E applied is the actual applied potential, E 0 is depicted as the theoretical equilibrium value, and iR is the ohmic correction under similar conditions. Normally the three overpotential values obtained from the polarization curve at a current density of 1 (η 1), 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) and 100 mA cm−2 (η 100) are used to evaluate the electrocatalytic activity of a catalyst. The onset point of the reaction is usually denoted as h1. The benchmark to compare the activity of electrocatalysts is always η 10. This is to match the 12.3% efficiency for photoelectrochemical water splitting [6,73]. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that the overpotential is strongly dependent on the loading mass of active material on the electrode. Thus, to achieve a fair comparison of the activity of various electrocatalysts, it is recommended that the amount of loading mass should be normalized according to the electrode surface area [51,74]. Moreover, η 100 is another essential criterion for evaluation in practical applications. 2.4.2 Tafel plot Tafel slope (b) is another key parameter to indicate the activity of water splitting. Tafel slope can evaluate how fast the current density increases with increasing overpotential, hence examining the kinetics of an electrocatalyst. Generally, overpotential and current density are logarithmically related. According to Tafel Eq. (21), the Tafel slope can be fitted linearly on the Tafel plot [67,75]: (21) η = a + blogj where η is the overpotential, b is the Tafel slope and j is the current density respectively. From the Tafel plot, we can also get another important parameter, which is exchanged current density (j o). j o can obtain when the value of h is zero, the corresponding current density (j), is the exchange current density (j o). Generally, a high j o and smaller Tafel slope signify good catalytic activity. 2.4.3 Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) Electrochemical impedance analysis is a measurement to know the kinetics for the over potentially deposited hydrogen where the system was assumed as Langmuir adsorption isotherm [3,76]. The ionic, charge and ohmic resistance of the system and the charge transfer resistance will be the key descriptor that affects the water electrolysis process. EIS Nyquist plot provides information on the interface charge-transfer process (R ct). Besides that, the semicircle curve reflects the internal resistance of the catalytic system. The lower resistance resulted in faster charge transfer. 2.4.4 Turnover frequency (TOF) TOF is defined as the total number of molecules transformed into the desired product at each active site per unit of time. It reveals the intrinsic activity of electrocatalysts. TOF values can be estimated by Eq. (22) [6,67]: (22) TOF = jA/αFn where j is the current density in the polarization curve; A is the surface area of the working electrode; a is the number of electrons corresponding to HER or OER that generates per molar of the target product; F is Faraday constant and n is the number of moles of the active materials. Notably, it is almost impossible to precisely calculate the TOF value as not all atoms in a catalyst are having equal catalytic activity. However, TOF is still a useful parameter in comparing similar catalysts. 2.4.5 Stability Stability is one of the key parameters to evaluate the durability of the catalyst for practical applications. Two methods are usually utilized for electrocatalyst stability measurements [72,77]. Firstly, performing cyclic voltammetry measurement by measuring and comparing the polarization curve of the catalyst before and after 1000 cycles of cyclic voltammetry. Generally, if the overpotential remains close to the initial polarization curve, it demonstrates good stability. Another method is by using chronoamperometry or chronopotentiometry measurement. The change in potential over time can be measured at a specified current density, where a high retention rate represents excellent stability. 2.4.6 Faradaic efficiency (FE) FE is another imperative evaluation criterion to measure the electron utilization efficiency during the electrochemical process and is a direct method to measure the selectivity of the catalyst in HER and OER towards the desired product. It describes the efficiency by which the electric charge from the external circuit is conveyed into the water-splitting reactions [78]. Thereinto, the gas generated during water splitting can be measured using the water displacement method or gas chromatography (GC). To calculate the FE for HER and OER, Faraday's Laws of electrolysis is obeyed to compare the experimental and calculated theoretical amount of gas. A higher FE value is desired, as it represents lesser energy loss during the reaction. Based on the literature, most HER electrocatalysts can achieve a high FE. However, OER which is a complex and sluggish process will affect the overall FE as energy loss was observed [79]. The FE can be obtained by measuring the ratio of gas H2 or O2 produced experimentally (n a) and theoretically (n t) (Eq. 23) [51,73]. (23) F a r a d a i c E f f i c i e n c y = n t n a = b F n a I t where b denotes the electro number for O2 and H2 (mol−1), F represents Faraday's Constant (96485 C mol−1), I is the constant current applied and t is the reaction time. 2.4.7 Electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) ECSA is utilized to estimate the total number of active sites on the surface of the working electrode and it is dependent on varying electrochemical processes and catalytic material [72]. ECSA can be measured based on electrochemical double-layer charging of the electrocatalytic surface [80]. In a non-Faradaic region, to determine ECSA the electrochemical double-layer capacitance can be measured by cyclic voltammetry test at different scan rates. The calculation of ECSA is illustrated as follows (Eq. 24): (24) ECSA = C DL/C s where is the double-layer capacitance of electrode material, and C s is the specific capacitance of the electrocatalyst with different values when it is in solutions of different pH. Typically, C s values are between 0.015 and 0.110 mF cm−2 in H2SO4 and 0.022 and 0.130 mF cm−2 in NaOH or KOH solution [25,81]. In general, a larger ECSA indicates that more active sites are exposed and more reactants and intermediates are absorbed in the reaction, enhancing the kinetics of the process. 2.5 Catalytic mechanisms Catalytically active sites are one of the most important descriptors during the design of electrocatalysts. It refers to the specific surface site that contribute to the activity of catalysts, and is accessible by the reactants (Fig. 7 ). At this point, surface active site has higher activity when compare to other surface atoms during the chemical reaction. It is crucial to identify the catalytically active sites to further deepen one understanding of electrocatalytic reactions and to better design the catalysts. The conventional way to identify heterostructure catalysts active sites were identify by preparing single crystalline catalysts of different sizes with several assumptions and correlating the particle sizes with the corresponding activity [82,83]. However, this method is indirect and some inconsistency of particle sizes might be produced. In recent years, evaluating the presence of active sites in situ characterization to monitor the surfaces and solid/liquid interfaces of catalysts has gained researchers attraction to evaluate the active sites. Some of the characterization methods include X-ray diffraction (XRD), surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). Additionally, DFT calculations can play their role in aiding the experimental work to identify the active sites of various reactions. 2.5.1 In situ experimental characterization To further support the reaction pathways and catalytic active sites, some in situ spectroscopic techniques have been employed. These techniques have proven effective in probing the real-time catalyst structural change as well as knowing the reaction key intermediates under operando conditions. This characterization method provides a comprehensive understanding to researchers of the entire electrocatalytic system. In this section, we will discuss some common in situ techniques, including in situ XRD, XAS, and surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy. XRD is a form of elastic scattering that can reveal the crystallographic information of the catalyst. Usually, a special in situ cell is required for real-time detection. Liu et al. [84] tailored a cell with a radial penetration window for XRD analysis. The experimental conditions were integrated with their cell as shown in (Fig. 8(a) ). However, there is a limitation of the in situ XRD where the local sites of the catalysts are not possible to detect. In another study, a hierarchical porous nanopolyhedron architecture (CS@HPP) was fabricated and in situ XRD was carried out. The cell surface was initially probed at a rate of 0.1 C and charged with different voltages. The results can confirm the deposition and decomposition of the catalyst and the acceleration of the performance of the catalyst. Additionally, Li's group fabricated CoS2/Cu2S-NF porous electrocatalysts and after charge and discharged progress for in situ XRD, the results (Fig. 8(b)) confirmed that the material was stable at wide working potential. Besides XRD, Raman spectroscopy is also another powerful tool on investigating the intrinsic activity of porous materials. Fig. 8(c) shows the reaction cell configuration for in situ Raman measurements. For instance, Zhou et al. [85] employed in situ Raman spectroscopy to probe the surface of Ni, Fe and NiFe foam electrodes in real-time at different potentials. Based on the in situ Raman results, NiFe foam demonstrated the highest active sites as it produced a large amount of active species starting at a low potential of 1.425 V (Fig. 8(d)). Previous reports suggested that metal sulfide transformed to metal (oxy)hydroxides after OER and the resultant M-OOH phase was detained as the actual active species for OER. For example, Wu et al. [86] observed the arise of δ(Ni3+–O) and ν(Ni3+–O) bonds of NiOOH phases at 1.34 V, which corresponds to the LSV curve value of the onset of the Ni oxidation peak. Herein, the active sites were increased for the electrocatalyst after adding Ni3S2. In general, in situ Raman spectroscopy contributes valuable information of nature catalytic active sites, making it a crucial descriptor for identifying the reaction pathway. Nevertheless, other techniques are necessary to complement more information on the catalyst surface. Beyond XRD and Raman, significant developments have occurred in the field of in situ XAS. In situ XAS spectra revealed that the exfoliated ultrathin bimetal NiCo-UMOFNs had a higher fraction of oxidized Ni, attributed to the greater active sites of NiCo-UMOFs [87]. Interestingly, in addition to determining the structural modulation and active sites, in situ XAS can prove the high stability of a catalyst. As such, Feng et al. [88] performed both XAS and DFT studies and it was found that the XAS further proved that the catalysts are highly stable after a long time reaction. The oxidation state of atomic sites can further validate the metal-support interaction that can be stabilized by atomic doping sites [89]. In short, in situ XAS not only clarifies changes in the oxidation state and electronic structure around the excited atom during the catalytic reactions, but also confirms the stability of the catalyst during electrochemical reactions. 2.5.2 Theoretical calculation In general, the adsorption capacity of active sites and the catalysts’ conductivity are the descriptors to determine intrinsic activity. To effectively lower the energy barrier of the catalytic process, the adsorption energy needs to be increased. Furthermore, to improve the chemical absorptivity the electron density needs to be tailored at the active sites. Recently, there has been increasing simulation-guided understanding of the reactivity mechanisms to collaborate with experimental. DFT calculation is a powerful auxiliary tool to reveal the OER and HER mechanisms. They have been widely employed to predict the adsorption free energy, volcano plots, and d-band centers to preliminary screen the electrocatalysts. In addition, information on the activation energy and electronic structure of catalyst was provided, giving a better guide on selecting and exploring suitable electrocatalytic materials. Analyzing adsorption energies of intermediates on active sites through different reaction pathways can elucidate the relationship between the structures and catalysts activity. Li et al. [90] has studied Co2P (001) to investigate the reaction pathways of HER and OER. After incorporating Ni and Fe atoms, the adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) of HER decreases from –0.54 to –0.26 eV. The homogeneous distribution of Ni and Fe atoms optimizes ΔG H*, which further enhances the electrocatalytic activity. While for OER, from the calculated ΔG H* the rate limiting step is the formation of OOH* intermediates for the Ni-Co-P NBs and Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs. The activity trend of P-doped NiCoFe(OH)2 located at a position with the lowest free energy, suggesting the high occurrence of CO4+ ions with the best intrinsic activity. To have an in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanism, Feng et al. [88] carry out DFT calculation for FeNi-LDH and S-doped FeNi-LDH. Before doping sulfur, *O and *OOH are the potential limiting step of OER. Nevertheless, after S-treatment the reaction path was modified (Fig. 8(e)). Herein, the molecular oxygen was produced with a low energy of 1.0 eV, through the new catalytic mechanisms. In this case, the sulfur treatment is a good candidate to provide the new catalytic mechanism for OER. To effectively model the desired catalyst, both fine in situ characterization and computational calculation are indispensable. Understanding the fine structure of the material by fitting the characterization spectra can be a laborious task, however, with the aid of DFT a more precise and quick process could be achieved. Bringing in light of the reaction mechanism and material structures of different modified and unmodified electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, DFT calculations and in situ characterizations would contribute to the engineering of a versatile next-generation electrocatalyst. 3 Preparation of porous electrocatalyst 3.1 Structural design principles of porous electrocatalysts for oriented applications In the past decade, remarkable achievements have been made in designing various porous nanoarchitecture catalysts, leading to the generation of diverse porous based catalysts. In the overall water-splitting process, both HER and OER take place on the electrochemical surface of the electrocatalyst. Therefore, a thoughtful approach to the rational design consideration and strategies for porous nanostructures becomes crucial. This strategy aims to furnish the electrocatalysts with abundant electrochemical active surface area, abundant active sites, enhanced electrical conductivity and efficient mass/electron transport. Active sites are among the most critical design criteria to improving electrocatalyst performance. In terms of active sites, it is essential that the designed catalyst is anticipated to possess a high specific surface area to fully expose the intrinsic active sites. Porous nanoarchitecture catalyst exhibits a large specific surface area providing an excellent mass transfer channel for the electrocatalytic process. In addition, the porous structure maximizes the usage of active sites during the reactions [92]. However, simply increasing the concentration of the active sites is not adequate to improve the activity of all electrocatalysts. In addition to that, the porous-based electrocatalysts should be rationally designed to meet the requirement of mass transport between the micropores and bulk solution. This is to ensure the optimal accessibility of active sites by reactants. Moreover, as the reaction involves a three-phase condition (gas-liquid-solid), a combination of different porous structures can optimize the catalysts, electrolyte and product mass transport process. Based on previous studies, hierarchical porosity at different scales provides a higher specific surface area [93]. Multimodal pore size distribution with different morphology interconnected macro-, micro-, and mesopores can productively channel the electrolytes and electrons toward active sites. To achieve high electrical conductivity for enhanced electron transport, the catalysts are expected to have strong interactions between structures. This requires modulating the electronic structure to a favourable state for electrocatalytic applications. Furthermore, creating porosity in some of the metal-based catalysts such as iridium-based perovskites, and intermetallic borides that possess outstanding HER and OER performance is inherently difficult. New approaches on mild synthetic conditions and tuning on electronic structure are essential to be explored. 3.2 Hydrothermal/solvothermal method The hydrothermal/solvothermal synthesis method is a facile synthesis strategy in the preparation of samples, which involves heating a reaction mixture (containing precursors, surfactants and reducing agent) within a sealed autoclave. Generally, heterogeneous chemical reactions will be involved in autoclaves at a temperature higher than room temperatures and under a pressure of higher than 1 atm [26]. In hydrothermal/solvothermal reactions, the initialized high temperature and autogenous pressure can accelerate the reaction rate, allowing the formation of crystalline materials with unique morphology [38,94,95]. The morphology, size and lattice orientation could be manipulated by controlling the factors, including the concentration of precursors, solution pH, temperature, stabilizer and reaction time [96]. There are several general approaches in the formation of porous structure for example with different precursors by using soft and hard templates and introducing 3D substrates to load the electrocatalysts [97,98]. The metal-based nanocrystals prepared by this method show uniform distribution and reduced agglomeration of particles [99]. To this end, substantial efforts have been devoted to developing low-cost and transition metal-based electrocatalysts (chalcogenides, oxides, phosphides and carbides) [100–105]. Transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) are one of the earliest extensively investigated groups of electrocatalysts. TMCs mainly include Sulfides (S), Selenides (Se) and Tullerides (Te). Typically, TMCs are employed as promising electrocatalysts owing to their fascinating electronic structures, high intrinsic activity, long-term stability even in harsh environments (strong acids or alkalis), tunable morphology, low cost, and environmentally friendly. Therefore, in the past few years, extensive attention has been given rise to them for HER, OER, and OWS. One of the most common transition metal sulfides which have been extensively investigated was MoS2 [106,107]. For instance, Zhao et al. [107] reported the synthesis of 3D porous molybdenum disulfide/nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (MoS2/N-rGO) hydrogel through a one-pot hydrothermal method (Fig. 9(a) ). To enhance the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts, the surface structure and interface is a key feature that will be required [106]. The pore structure of the hydrogel is ranging from hundreds of nanometers to micrometers. The 3D porous framework was formed by the interconnected lamellar nanosheets when GO was added to MoS2 nanosheets, forming a hydrogel. The as-synthesized MoS2 with lateral size of dozens of nanometers vertically adhered onto the surface of the N-rGO framework (Fig. 9(b)) offered a large surface area, hence exposing abundant electrocatalytic active sites. As reported, increasing pH value ranging (from 10.3 to 11.4) has a negligible effect on the morphology of MoS2/N-rGO hydrogels. NH3 × H2O serves as the source for the N-dopant, it affects the lateral size, density and exposed edges of MoS2-sheet clusters (Fig. 9(c)). Amount of N-doping needs to be tuned to the optimum amount to avoid excess N incorporation, which in turn causes agglomeration and reconnection of MoS2 nanosheets. The porous structure can assist in accelerating protons and electrons transfer and also reduce the electrolyte transport limitation [108]. This multi-component material shows enhanced electrocatalytic activity due to the synergistic effect from the interface of MoS2 nanosheets and N-rGO. Another typical example that ascribed the MoS2 synthesis was reported by Xu and co-workers [106] which comprised a sheet-on-sheet hierarchical porous MoS2/NiS2 supported on carbon cloth (CC) (Fig. 9(d)). The as-prepared porous electrocatalysts displayed remarkably high HER and OER activities. The outstanding performance was mainly attributed to the strong synergistic effect between the heterointerface of MoS2 and NiS2 nanosheets. The unique sheet-on-sheet heterostructure demonstrates good exposure to large surface area in the electrolyte and fully exposed edge active sites. This enhances the charge transfer employed to provide multiscale channels for intensified mass/charge transfer [109,110]. The formation of mesopores between the nanosheets is mainly distributed in the range of 2–4 nm. In general, characterization of porous materials will be done through physisorption for surface area assessment with the Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) method [111]. This method is the most widely used method to evaluate the specific surface area of porous and finely divided materials. To probe the accessible surface area suitable adsorption isotherm types will be used. Theoretically, different pore sizes will give rise to different types of isotherms. Typically for type II or type IV(a) it will be for mesoporous materials, while type I(a) and I(b) isotherms are for microporous materials. Besides MoS2, nickel and cobalt sulfides synthesized from hydrothermal/solvothermal methods have been substantially studied as electrocatalysts for water splitting [112–114]. Zhang's group [114] fabricated a 3D catalyst of self-interconnected porous Ni-Co disulfide networks grown on carbon cloth [(Ni0.33Co0.67)S2NWs/CC] (Fig. 10(a) ). Carbon cloth (CC), which acts as a substrate in this catalyst exhibits outstanding properties including high thermal and electrical conductivity, satisfactory costs and high mechanical strength [115]. Sulfuration is one of the main processes, which convert the Ni-Co nanoneedles (Ni-Co NNs) into a porous structure. The shrinkage and cross-linkage of adjacent NNs during the sulfuration process formed the porous structure. The formation of the mesoporous structure increased the surface area, and quantity of the active sites and eventually increased the mass transfer capability. Transition metal selenides and transition metal tellurides demonstrate excellent electrocatalytic properties in water splitting. By adopting a simple hydrothermal/solvothermal strategy, Liang and co-workers [116] prepared a cobalt-doped nickel selenide (Co-NiSe) which possessed a 3D porous nanoflower structure solvothermally grown on the nickel foam (NF) with a large quantity of catalytic active sites (Fig. 10(b)). The flower-like Co-NiSe were adorned on the surface of the Ni foam substrate forming a 3D porous electrocatalyst [116]. The ultra-thin nanosheets are unique as they can confine electron without interlayer interaction, enables greatly compelling electronic properties, and have maximum mechanical flexibility and the large lateral size with ultrathin thickness demonstrates high specific surface area [117]. Furthermore, doping of cobalt changed the morphology of NiSe to small-size nanoflowers. In addition, this heteroatom doping results in surface defects, exposing more surface-active sites providing a material with high catalytic activity. Another TMC is transition metal tellurides, which express excellent electrocatalytic activity. Bhat et al. [118] developed nanostructured 2D porous hollow nickel telluride nanosheets under hydrothermal conditions via anion-exchange-reaction. The 2D nanosheet with an average edge thickness of ~55 nm and a mean width of ~350 nm had a morphology of hexagonal shape crystals [118]. For instance, the anion exchange of the precursors, which was Ni(OH)2 nanosheets lead to the formation of porous hollow nickel telluride nanostructures (Fig. 10(c) and 10(d)). The nanopores have a pore diameter of 2.65 nm. Sulfides, selenides, and tellurides are all belong to the transition-metal chalcogenides. They show promise as materials for HER, and the specific transition metal used is a critical factor. For example, many of these materials have been combined with nickel due to its conductivity and hydrogen adsorption capabilities, that results in optimal electrocatalytic activity. The special characteristics of transition metal carbides, owing to the similar electron density and catalytic properties to Pt-group metals, have been reported as prominent electrocatalysts for HER and OER applications [119,120]. Li et al. [121] synthesized a porous carbon-based bimetal electrocatalyst of Mo0.84Ni0.16-Mo2C@NC nanosphere by a one-pot self-assembled hydrothermal method (Figs. 11(a) and 11(b) ). To adjust the spatial distance of metal sites, a zeolite imidazolate framework (ZIF) with Zn element as sacrificial metal was used. Notably, this Mo0.84Ni0.16-Mo2C@NC hybrid showed 3D pores with an average size of 0.879 nm, which enhanced mass transfer. Benefitting from the synergism effect of Mo2C and 3D porous structure, the catalyst can reduce overpotential and promote superior catalytic activity. The experimental result demonstrated that a low overpotential of 151 and 285 mV was required for both HER and OER in 1 mol L−1 KOH media to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Similarly, porous electrocatalyst of N-doped Mo2C@C nanoparticles self-encapsulated in nanospheres can be obtained from a one-pot solvothermal method followed by hydrogen calcination reported by Hu et al. (Fig. 11(c)) [122]. The sphere-like nanoparticles of N-Mo2C@C were well maintained and the agglomeration was reduced after high-temperature calcination (Fig. 11(d)). Moreover, the emergence of mesopores in this electrocatalyst is a result of the breakdown of acetamide, generating gas-filled pores when exposed to elevated temperatures. This reduction in particle agglomeration and the introduction of porous features can significantly enhance catalytic activity by expanding the interaction between the material's surface area and the electrolyte. Leading to more available active sites becoming accessible within the interior. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been widely used in electrocatalysis because of their tunable architecture, superior stability and cost-effectiveness have provided a promising possibility in developing bifunctional catalysts with excellent electrocatalytic activities [3,123,124]. For instance, Li's group fabricated a novel material of Co-doped ZnO nanowires in situ grown on highly conductive carbon fabric substrates (Co-ZnO@CF) (Fig. 12(a) ). It was observed that 1D nanowires were formed, and uniformly covered the carbon fibers of the substrate. Interestingly, this electrocatalyst demonstrates a 3D porous architecture of biomimetic structure at the microscopic level (Fig. 12(b)) [125]. The porous architecture endowed high mass loading of active material without performance decay. Transition metal-based spinel compounds [AB2X4; where A, B = metal (A¹B), X = chalcogens] have drawn considerable attention due to their excellent structural stability, easy synthesis and possessed tunable electrocatalytic activity. In 1997, Nikolov et al. [126] investigated that porous spinel oxide NiCo2O4 electrocatalytic activity in OER was better than that of the original Co3O4. This stemmed from the increase in the number of active sites. Deng et al. [127] fabricated an urchin-like 3D peapod NiCo2O4@C bifunctional electrocatalyst by hydrothermal and followed by thermal annealing method (Fig. 12 (c)). During the hydrothermal reaction, the nanoneedles self-assembled into the microsphere precursor, and then polymerized glucose was deposited on the surface of the precursor. Subsequently, the thermal annealing process molded the as-prepared precursors into a peapod-like structure, with these steps the 3D porous electrocatalyst with a pore size of range 2–5 nm was formed (Fig. 12(d)) [127]. The 3D porous structure ensured the contact of the electrolyte and the active nanoparticles, which enhanced the electroconductivity. Moreover, Ni2Co4 nanoparticles were confined within graphitized carbon-coating that prevented aggregation and agglomeration of nanoparticles. When aggregation and agglomeration were prevented, there will be more available active sites that are accessible for the catalytic reaction. Moving on, taking into consideration of the electronegativity of P sites to trap protons and the unique electronic structure of transition metal phosphide, it has recently emerged as a promising electrocatalyst. CoP-embedded N-doped carbon nanoflowers (CoP@NCNFs) with 3D hierarchical mesoporous structures were fabricated by a combination of hydrothermal and phosphidation. The fabricated material exhibits a 3D hierarchical mesoporous structure, having a specific surface area of 9.8 m2 g−1 and a pore size range from 2 to 120 nm. The pores formed on the nanoflakes of CoP@NCNFs were related to the phosphating reaction (Figs. 12(e) and 12(f)) [128]. The formation of numerous pores resulted in more defect sites, where the defective sites were advantageous to the adsorption and activation of reactants, thereby maximizing the electrocatalytic activity [129]. Likewise, Anjum et al. [130] utilized CoP and synthesized the S-doped CoP electrocatalyst by direct growth of S-doped CoP nanoparticles on a highly porous substrate (Carbon cloth and Nickel foam). However, this electrocatalyst was prepared by a novel and eco-friendly thiourea-phosphate-assisted solvothermal route [130]. Due to the heteroatoms doping of sulfur particles on the metal phosphides, it enhanced the electrical conductivity and generated ample active sites for reactions. In addition, charge transfer characteristics were improved too, which was proven by the reduction of R ct and R d values as compared to those undoped CoPs. Undoubtedly, the hydrothermal/solvothermal method serves as a potent technique for synthesizing various porous electrocatalysts. This method tailors the morphology of products and form hierarchical nanostructures (nanoflowers and urchin-like nanostructures) autogenously. In addition, the porous structure can expose more active sites and defects can be introduced into the final materials, thereby enhancing the electrocatalytic activity. The catalyst that is grown on a porous substrate often shows robust and excellent electrocatalytic performance. However, the fabrication is rather not economical for large-scale applications as only a small amount of electrocatalyst adheres to the substrate, while the rest remains at the bottom of the autoclave, leading to inefficient chemical usage and inhibiting the feasibility of mass-producing electrocatalyst. 3.3 Thermal decomposition strategy The thermal decomposition strategy is a method that utilizes heat treatment. Thermal decomposition of precursors, accompany by gas escape or the removal of surfactants is the main reason for the generation of pores on the final product [38,131]. Pyrolysis and calcination at high temperatures are one of the main approaches in thermal decomposition strategy [132]. Due to the straightforward and dependable nature of the synthesis method, it has become a widely used approach in creating porous electrocatalysts. This section provides an overview and discussion of porous materials that have been recently prepared using the thermal decomposition strategy. Using heteroatom-doped carbon materials, which is an effective approach to adjusting the physical/chemical properties, possesses promising electrocatalytic activities [38]. For instance, heteroatoms doped 3D porous carbonaceous electrodes were prepared by using melamine as the nitrogen source under carbonization. Herein, a hybrid of Co3Co4/Co nanoparticles incorporated in the N-doped porous carbon matrix (Co3Co4/Co-NPS) fabricated by facile ion exchange and thermal processes was reported (Fig. 13(a) ). Alginate polymer having an “egg-box” structure was used as the precursor to prepare porous carbon materials. As shown in (Fig. 13(b)), some aggregations occurred, but the Co-based NPs embedded in the tube-like carbon matrix were still well dispersed. The synthesized porous electrocatalyst has both small mesopores and large mesopores with pore sizes ranging from 2.2 to 5.6 nm and 12.2 to 32.1 nm, respectively [133]. Therein, the large mesopores were due to the interconnected voids between carbon nanoparticles in the hybrid material, and the small mesopores arose from the release of H2O and CO2 during the pyrolysis of alginate [134]. Such a porous structure enhanced the contact of electrocatalytic and the interior of the catalyst, exposure of abundant active sites and thus enhancing mass transport for high electrocatalytic activity. Sun et al. [135] fabricated a novel NiO/NiCo2O4 heterostructure by two-stage calcination of nickel-cobalt bimetallic hydroxide precursors (Fig. 13(c)). This bimetallic electrocatalyst illustrated a uniform 3D flower-like microsphere shape assembled by 2D nanosheets. Intriguingly, the nanostructures were affected by the reaction time. Prolonged reaction time provides larger open spaces and a more uniform distribution of Ni-Co precursors (Fig. 13(d)) [135]. This uniform 3D framework could provide more surface active sites and easier mass diffusion. On the other hand, as the calcination temperature increased, the nanoscale porosity of the NiO/NiCo2O4 heterostructure was higher and thus it possessed better OER performance. It was illustrated that the optimum conditions for NiCo-precursors reaction time was 10 mins and calcination temperature of NiO/NiCo2O4 heterostructure is 500 °C. Metal-organic frameworks (MOF) are commonly known for the porous structure constructed by metal and organic ligands. MOFs possess high specific surface areas, high porosity and tunable structures [137,138]. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are one of the subsets of the MOF families that are widely used as precursors for the preparation of Co-based electrocatalysts. For example, Zhao and co-workers prepared cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated in porous carbons by carbonizing the core-shell ZIF67@ZIF8 at 900 °C under Ar atmosphere for 6 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 (Fig. 13(e)) [136]. Pan et al. [139] reported a novel hybrid nanostructure with CoP NPs embedded in an N-doped carbon nanotube hollow polyhedron (NCNHP) derived from core-shell ZIF-8@ZIF-67 through a pyrolysis-oxidation-phosphidation strategy (Fig. 14(a) ). The as-fabricated CoP/NCNHP catalyst showed a hollow polyhedron made up of carbon nanotubes with high porosity (Fig. 14(b) and (c)) [139]. Both of the ZIF-8@ZIF-67 showed a well-defined rhombic dodecahedral structure and a similar porous structure as the core-shell, which was attributed to the core-shell structure of ZIF-8@ZIF67. When the temperature reached above 900 °C, the ZIF-8 shell was transformed into porous carbons to promote diffusion kinetics. On the contrary, cobalt improved the graphitization degree of carbon at the same condition, leading to the transformation into porous carbons. It is well-known that to enhance the performance of electrocatalysts various design strategies have been carried out. Recently, Li et al. [140] fabricated a Fe doped-Ni5P4/NiFeOH hybrid nanosheets with a double control strategy by adopting a doping and vacancy creation strategy to enhance the catalyst performance (Fig. 14(d)). When NaH2PO2 decomposed to PH3 gas during thermal treatment, the acidic environment chemically etched the surfaces of the precursors creating a hierarchical porous structure (Figs. 14(e)–(g)) [140]. In addition, oxygen vacancies were created by the reaction between H2/PH3 and lattice oxygen during the phosphidation process. The Fe-Ni5P4/NiFeOH with a phosphidation temperature of 350 °C showed a high Faradaic efficiency of 100% for both the HER and OER test, manifesting that the as-prepared electrocatalyst is highly efficient and durable towards HER and OER. The catalytic performance was improved by the porous structure with abundant edge sites and Fe doping, which benefited the exposure of active sites and accelerated the charge transfer. Co-currently, the electrolyte adsorption and permeation were improved by abundant oxygen vacancies. In short, thermal decomposition is a facile and convenient method in the preparation of porous materials. The materials produced using this method tend to exhibit chemical stability, possess a significant specific surface area, and display high crystallinity. Nevertheless, there is still significant potential for enhancement, given the limitations, including the reduction in surface area caused by undesired agglomeration triggered by thermal treatment, the substantial energy consumption, and safety concerns associated with high temperatures. 3.4 Electrochemical deposition The electrochemical deposition strategy is widely considered as an efficient route to fabricating porous electrocatalysts. This is a commonly used method for the deposition of metal-based nanomaterials on different substrates to prepare the self-supported electrode. This strategy uses an external electric field to deposit the required metal on the electrode surface through cathodic or anodic electrolysis in the corresponding electrolyte. The morphology and thickness of metal films can be controlled by changing the electrode potential and current density. In a word, this powerful and scalable technique provides the electrocatalysts with a unique shape or composition for industrial requirements. For example, Yu et al. [141] reported the few-layer NiFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets on Cu nanowire cores supported on Cu foam (3D- Cu@NiFeLDH) (Figs. 15(a)–(c) ). NiFeLDH NSs grown vertically on the Cu NWs, leaving lots of exposed edges, and the characteristic of the nanosheets which is ultrathin offered more active sites [141]. The nanosheets were interconnected with each other, leading to the formation of highly porous morphology, which enhanced the electrocatalytic activity. Cheng et al. [142] developed a 3D freestanding porous Cu foam in situ armored CoNi alloy nanosheet arrays (CoNi@CF) employing CoCl2 and NiCl2 as the initial metal source by an energy-efficient electrodeposition strategy (Fig. 15(d)). Cu foam, which was having interesting properties of light weight, high surface area, a large amount of pore volume and high stability of adsorption, was used as a substrate [143]. Pore volume can be determined via the BET nitrogen adsorption isotherm method. To further characterize the pore size distribution various models, such as the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. In this study, the effects of the ratio of metal salt precursor on the morphology of the product were shown. It was found that when Co/Ni ratio was 4:6, a 3D porous hierarchical nanosheet arrays/Cu foam structure was formed. The optimum ratio for the formation of a perfect Co/Ni nanosheet array structure was 3:7, as further reduced in ratio led to a small number of tiny nanosheets formed with Cu foam covered with granular structure (Figs. 15(e) and (f)). It was noted that the ordered nanosheet array, interconnected porous structure and the synergistic effect of CoNi alloys promoted the excellent electrocatalytic performance. 2D porous nanosheets grown on a conductive substrate, especially 3D foam, are regarded as the most attractive electrocatalysts, as it provides highly desirable advantages, including good mechanical adhesion and less blockage of active sites [144,145]. Therefore, a self-templating fabrication of thin porous CoSe2 nanosheets arrays (p-CoSe2/CC) in situ grown on carbon cloth prepared via a combination of electrodeposition and vapor selenization treatment was reported by Wan and co-workers [146] (Figs. 16(a) and (b) ). The thickness of the catalyst increased and pore structures appeared on the surface as a result of surface shrinkage after selenization. The 3D porous structure furnished them with a large active surface area, which promoted electrocatalytic activity. Moreover, the hybrid structure of the electrocatalyst enhanced the efficient electron conductivity and mass transport. The rational design of bimetallic compounds promotes the improvement of transition metal-based electrocatalysts [46]. In 2018, Pei and co-workers [147] synthesized a 3D hierarchical structured CoFe-layered double hydroxide (CoFe-LDH) nanosheets directly grown on nickel foam. The nanosheets grew and hydroxide loading gradually increased as the deposition time increased, creating a 3D porous structure. However, when it reached an optimum value of 400 s as reported by the team, the porous structure decreased (Figs. 16(c) and (d)) [147]. Besides, the valence state on the surface was affected by electrodeposition time, which influenced the electrocatalytic performance [148]. Other characteristics that affect the electrocatalytic performance include the synergistic effects between metallic characters of Co and Fe and the conductivity of the metals. In the same year, Kim et al. [149] developed a 3D porous Co-Fe-P foam with Fe/Co ratio of 1.1 (Fig. 11(e)). This electrodeposited Co-Fe-P foam served as an electrode directly as it was free from binders and the microstructure of the electrode could be controlled by electrodeposition conditions. The incorporation of Fe in Co-P promoted the binding energy shift of Co and the 3D porous structure, which was related to the large electrochemical active surface area, ECSA (798.2 cm2), leading to a superior catalytic activity towards HER and OER. In general, the electrochemical serves as a valuable method for porous electrocatalytic materials. This approach is known for its speed, cost-effective, and straightforward, allowing easy customization of the architecture and chemical composition of the resulting porous materials. Additionally, this synthesis method typically does not necessitate additional capping agents or reductants, making it advantageous for potential industrial scaling to meet industrial needs. Researchers can fine tune the properties such as thickness and roughness by adjusting deposition parameters. In addition, this method is gaining increased attention due to its capability to provide uniform coatings, rendering it applicable in various domains, from electrocatalysts to corrosion protection. Nevertheless, this technique still has its drawbacks, including challenges in finely tuning the physical morphology, achieving poor crystallinity in the metal films deposited on various substrates and encountering issues related to uneven distribution and the formation of small nanoparticles. 3.5 Wet chemical strategy The wet chemical strategy is regarded as one of the conventional synthesis routes owing to its low cost and huge potential for mass production. Liquid-phase precursors or organic solutions are often used to produce a wide range of catalysts. Different from the traditional hydrothermal strategy, the metal substrates involved in the reaction system act as metal sources, in other words, the metal salts and bases are involved in the growth of metal components [38,150]. The reaction temperature plays an important role in catalysts growth and morphology [151,152]. For instance, Peng et al. [153] reported a novel integrated 3D hierarchical porous Co9S8/WS2 electrocatalysts with array structures on a conductive Ti plate prepared by a hydrothermal-sulfurization hybridization process (Fig. 17(a) ). Through the Kirkendall reaction, the pores were formed on Co9S8 nanomaterials, then WS2 nanosheets were coated on the surface of nanomaterials and resulting in the formation of Co9S8/WS2 composites. Revealed by DFT calculations, the synergistic effect between Co9S8 and WS2 facilitated faster charge transfer at the interface. Furthermore, the unique 3D hierarchical structure, porous array structure and self-supporting features produced lead to a high surface area and increased the exposed active sites that lead to enhanced electrocatalytic performance for water splitting. Based on similar considerations, a directly grown nickel sulfide nanosheet on Ni foam (NiS/NF) was reported with a similar fabrication method. The synthesis of this electrocatalyst was done in a Na2S aqueous solution under hydrothermal conditions [154]. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are another attractive family of catalysts for electrochemical water splitting. Besides that, mass transport is also an important factor that affects the performance of electrocatalysts during electrocatalysis. During the process of HER and OER three-phase transport (gas, liquid and solid) may involve, hence the construction of porous structures is an effective strategy to enhance molecule diffusion [155,156]. For instance, Lian et al. [157] fabricated Co0.6Fe0.4P nanoframes by adopting the bimetallic MOF-Co-Fe Prussian Blue Analogue (Co-Fe PBAs) as the template. This 3D framework of Co-Fe bimetal phosphides was prepared by a combination of template growth, etching and phosphorization (Fig. 17(b)). Due to the porous structure with a pore volume of 0.53 cm3 g−1, and large specific surface area, mass transfer and charge transportation were promoted. Ma's group developed NiCoP@Cu3P heterostructure on 3D Cu-foam. NiCoP nanostructures showed a 3D micro hierarchical structure, which endowed a large surface area and increased active sites. Notably, the porous structure and roughness of the surface appeared after phosphorization (Figs. 17(c) and (d)) [158]. On the other hand, the synergistic effect of the NiCoP@Cu3P heterostructure enhanced the specific surface area as well as improved mass and electron transport ability. Besides metal phosphides, transition metal oxide is also a potential candidate as a non-noble metal electrocatalyst for water splitting. Jin and co-workers have reported porous MoO2 nanosheets directly grown on nickel foam by a combination of the wet-chemical route and annealing treatment without using a binder (Figs. 17(e) and (f)) [44]. Binder reduced the effective catalytic activity as it blocks the active sites of the porous electrocatalysts and reduces the gas permeability [159]. Hence, it was always a challenge to synthesize the direct growth of porous MoO2 on the substrates without a binder. Moreover, the nickel foam was uniformly covered by porous MoO2 nanosheets and when it was immersed into the electrolyte, the nanosheets were covered by the electrolyte, thus providing a quick supply and short ion-diffusion system. Compared to single metal-based electrocatalysts, the combination of two different metals could significantly boost the electrocatalytic activity, due to the synergistic effect between the interaction of metals. Wang et al. [160] prepared a NiFe-based electrocatalyst through a spontaneous galvanic replacement (GRR) reaction, which was a classical single-step reaction by immersing the 3D iron foam in the Ni2+ cations solution. A layer of NiFe-based film of uniform nanosheets was formed on the iron foam surface, which produced a hierarchically structured 3D electrode (NiFeO x /IF) (Fig. 18(a) ) [160]. The nanosheets constituted a porous structure on the iron foam surface with pore sizes ranging from 30–50 nm, providing abundant active sites on the electrode surface (Figs. 18(b) and (c)). GRR is a redox process involving two different metals, driven by the potential difference of the metals. From Fig. 18(d), the surface atoms of Cu wire react with Ag+ ions in the AgNO3 solution. The reduction potential of Ag is higher as compared to Cu, therefore a layer of silver Ag will be covering the surface of Cu wires due to the redox process. Eventually the Cu atoms will undergo oxidation and become Cu2+ [161]. Furthermore, the bimetallic phosphide electrode (NiFe-P/IF) was fabricated with the subsequent phosphorization process. The integrated electrode displayed high structural strength, 3D hierarchical porous structure and excellent durability, which were suitable for efficient overall water splitting. Xuan's group reported Ni-Fe-P nanocubes from nickel-iron Prussian blue analogue (NiFe-PBA) template through the co-precipitation and phosphidation approach. The fabricated bimetallic materials have a rough and loose porous architecture due to the cube morphology with many particles interconnected. This special morphology was favorable for mass transfer and oxygen diffusion during the electrocatalysis process. Overall, the wet chemical method is novel and facile to prepare metal-based components and templates from precursors. Nevertheless, achieving a porous structure solely through the wet chemical process can be challenging. Thus, a combination of the different processes is needed to fabricate the porous structure, which can complicate the reaction process. For instance, process such as galvanic replacement reaction has been showing great potential in producing porous hollow structures. In spite of that, it only works when two different metals or metal oxides with reduction potential difference are designed. Additionally, it is necessary to ensure the uniform distribution of hosting material and the metal ions for a uniform distribution of porous hollow structure. During the reaction process, attention has to be given to avoid the formation of aggregates. Consequently, concerted efforts are necessary to address the challenges in developing high-efficiency porous electrocatalysts. 3.6 Other synthesis strategies Apart from the typical strategies mentioned above, there are some less common methods have also been developed to synthesize porous electrocatalysts in achieving the desired architecture. Some other novel methods to fabricate porous electrocatalysts are introduced here. The fabrication method can be divided into two types, “top-down” and “bottom-up” strategies. Typically, top-down strategies involve the exfoliation or successive reduction of a bulk material (e.g. ball milling). Ball milling is a low-cost and highly scalable mechanical process. This method is widely used in preparing porous electrocatalysts, as it breaks and reconstructs the chemical bonds, reducing the particle size and causing defects. For example, Qian et al. [162] prepared a 3D porous graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) network with 3D cubic NaCl as the template by ball-milling strategy (Fig. 19(d) ). The template furnished g-C3N4 with 3D porous networks and the aggregation of g-C3N4 was eventually averted during calcination [162]. Moreover, the block structure was broken into a porous structure through this synthesis method, which facilitated rapid electrolyte penetration and charge transfer. The 3D porous structure was tuned by adjusting the mass ratios of melamine and NaCl and it was found that the ratio of 1:90 showed abundant mesopore and macropore frameworks (Fig. 19(e)). The high melting point NaCl crystals stabbed into the g-C3N4 to separate the g-C3N4 sheets and subsequently 3D porous g-C3N4 was obtained. Further increase in the NaCl amount caused agglomeration during the ball milling process and the pores collapsed (Fig. 19(f)). This porous g-C3N4, which owed a controllable porosity and microstructure, acquired a large specific surface area and rapid mass transfer that was beneficial to the catalytic performance. Thus, ball milling is a top-down strategy that is highly feasible for the synthesis of the porous electrocatalyst. Proverbially, bottom-up strategy (e.g. chemical vapor deposition and atomic layer deposition) refers to the self-assembly reaction of small molecules and converting into nano/microstructures. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is one of the advanced fabrication techniques, which forms a thin film on a substrate [163–165]. Ultrathin nanostructures are beneficial as they enhance the surface area by reducing the thickness, exposing interior surface atoms to the surrounding, forming more defects and generating more active sites, which can ameliorate electrocatalytic performance. For instance, Jia et al. [164] created the ultrathin N-doped Mo2C nanosheets (N-Mo2C NSs) via the CVD route using dicyandiamide as the carbon source. MoO2 nanosheets grown on the quartz tube were utilized as template. The mixture of MoO2 nanosheets and dicyandiamide was placed in the tube furnace and gradually heated to 450 °C for 2 h then 700 °C for 2 h. Porous, ultrathin and hexagonal nanosheets could be obtained after the carbonization process at high temperature [164]. The BET results showed a specified surface area of 30.6 m2 g−1 with a pore size distribution of 2–40 nm and thickness of ~1.0 nm (Fig. 19(a)). The porous structure stemmed from the N-doping and carbonization. Zhao's group [165] reported a 2D cobalt phosphosulfide (CoPS) nanosheet synthesized with graphene oxide (GO) self-sacrificing template by the combination of chemical vapor deposition and wet-chemical method. The porous and ultrathin characteristics of the nanosheets were due to the GO self-sacrificing template (Figs. 19(b) and (c)) [165]. Typically, a mesoporous structure was formed with a pore diameter of 2–20 nm and a total pore volume of 0.022 cm3 g−1. The high electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of CoPS was attributed to the ultrathin and porous morphology. Such a ternary compound with 2D porous and ultrathin CoPs nanosheets showed high stability, high electron transport and reduced aggregation of active species during electrolysis [166,167]. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is also a facile method to prepare porous materials with a high specific surface area. ALD is a technique that grows thin films through adsorption. For instance, Tong et al. [168] reported 3D porous Co-doped Ni3S2 nanocones (Co12@Ni3S2/NF) by vulcanization of cobalt oxide nanofilm on porous nickel foam (NF) by ALD (400 cycles) and hydrothermal method (Fig. 19(g)). The as-prepared Co12@Ni3S2/NF showed a surface area of 2.34 m2 g−1 and a mesoporous structure with an average pore size of 11.61 nm. The increase in Co-doping transformed the morphology from leaf-like nanostructures to nanocones with a mean diameter of 100 nm and a length of 1 mm (Figs. 19(h) and (i)).
