It was believed that the excellent catalytic activity of Co12@Ni3S2/NF was attributed to the unique 3D porous nanocone structure with the combination of cobalt dopant, which improved the charge transfer and modulated the available active sites. Indeed, there exist numerous techniques for effectively creating highly active porous electrocatalysts, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. Notably, the hydrothermal/solvothermal approach stands out as one of the most widely embraced methods for fabricating electrocatalysts featuring diverse porous structures while being cost-effective and easily accessible. The thermal decomposition method is a straightforward means to fashion a porous framework, but it tends to reduce the surface area during thermal treatment and poses challenges in controlling pore structure. Given that each synthesis method has its strengths and weaknesses, a combination of various methods might be an attractive strategy for producing multifunctional electrocatalysts with outstanding performance. In the previous section, we introduce five primary methods, along with some less common methods for porous structure synthesis. Each of the synthesis methods offers distinct advantages and limitations. In practical synthesis, rational design principles and considerations need to be taken into account to enrich the synthesis techniques and strategies. Instead of relying on a single synthesis strategy, a combination of multiple methods can broaden the applicability of pore structure and material types. 3.7 Proposed techniques for porous electrocatalysts Despite the significant impact of porous nanoarchitecture catalysts in electrochemistry, there are still challenges in designing porous non-noble metal electrocatalysts with highly active components and hierarchical structures, a genuine requirement for practical application. Herein, a few synthesis strategies are proposed to implement in porous electrocatalysts for electrochemical reactions. The first proposed technique involves creating porous structured aerogel by using advanced synthesis methods like three-dimensional (3D) printing. From previous experimental studies, aerogel is a facile method to create bulk porous materials. However, the pore structures created are usually in random sizes and tuning the porous structure is challenging. Direct ink writing (DIW) 3D printing techniques enable researcher to leverage automation to fabricate aerogels with desired inner pore architecture while customizing the overall structure of the aerogel [169]. The catalysts gel in water is prepared and printed into a 3D printed simple thin sheet and sent to freeze drying. Herein, a simple self-supported catalyst can be formed. This method enables the catalyst gel to be modified based on the desired materials and to design multicomponent aerogels. The second proposed technique is by utilizing the ion intercalation process to form the porous structure. For instance, the intercalation of Mn2+ transformed the alkaline-treated V2CT x (MXene) into a 3D porous network with uniform nanoribbons and retains the conductive carbon framework. The intercalation of foreign species could increase the interlayer distance of VC2T x and modify the electronic structure [170]. Besides that, the intercalation of cations on MXene can break down the 2D nanosheets to form a unique porous structure. In Ti3C2T x the larger interlayer spacing is a more conducive environment for the rapid diffusion of H+ ions between the layers, enhancing the electron diffusion [171]. In some 2D materials such as MoS2, during intercalation process, phase changes occur, and lattice-mismatch-induced strain tunes the catalytic activity. This proposed strategy could serve as a solution for creating a hierarchical porous structure and rational design for strained electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. 4 Modification strategies for electrocatalytic water splitting A wide range of low-cost precious-metal-free electrocatalysts has been proposed to promote electrochemical activities. The most important factor for electrocatalytic performances is the intrinsic catalytic activity of each of the systems and it can be influenced by the active site, conductivity and electronic configuration. Hence, to further magnify the catalytic performance, different emerging strategies have been adopted. In the following sections, several strategies will be discussed, which comprise structure engineering, defect engineering, strain engineering and hybrid engineering. 4.1 Structure engineering The porous structure enlarges the surface area of the electrocatalysts, providing more catalytic active sites, and facilitating the diffusion of electrolytes and the transportation of products and reactants [172,173]. In light of these advantages, enormous efforts have been applied to regulate the morphology of catalysts. This is to prepare catalysts with lower overpotential, excellent stability and fast reaction kinetics. Porous structures can be generated via a sacrificial template method. For example, Anandhabadu et al. [174] used a zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) nanoplate as a self-sacrificial template to derive 2D porous cobalt phosphide (CoPO) nanosheets with abundant mesopores. SEM images of CoPO nanosheets showed well-distributed pores throughout the sheets (Fig. 20(a) ), which is caused by oxidation and volarization of carbon components in the ZIF-67 precursor. The unique 2D porous nanosheet architectured resulted in sufficient catalytic active sites and facilitated mass and electron transport during OER and HER. Remarkably, the CoPO nanosheets required an HER overpotential of 158 mV and delivered a catalytic current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH, with a Tafel slope of 101 mV dec−1. In addition, CoPO nanosheets showed excellent catalytic activity for OER with an overpotential of 280 mV to deliver a geometric current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 59 mV dec−1 (Figs. 20(b)–(d)). The low overpotential of CoPO nanosheets has surpassed the commercial RuO2 (395 mV), which was recognized as the state-of-the-art catalyst for OER. The low Tafel value of CoPO nanosheets denotes excellent HER and OER activities. In addition, CoPO nanosheets were directly integrated on nickel foam (NF) and the water electrolysis setup was illustrated as a superior water splitting system in alkaline conditions, presenting a low cell voltage of 1.52 V for 10 mA cm−2. This 2D porous nanosheet exhibited outstanding stability in long-term HER and OER processes (Fig. 20(e)). The porous nature of the material initiates the deposition of the catalysts throughout the entire inner space of the substrate. This enhances the rate at which reactant hydroxide ions are transported and dissipation of gaseous products. Wang et al. [175] designed a 2D Co-MOF nanosheet array on nickel formed by utilizing the CoO nanowall template. The self-sacrificial template provided a skeleton and Co2+ ions for Co-MOF growth. The 2D Co-MOF nanosheet arrays then underwent pyrolysis treatment and were converted into Ni@CoO@Co-MOFC composites (Fig. 20(f)) [175]. In 1 mol L−1 KOH, the as-prepared electrocatalysts exhibited great HER and OER catalytic performances with an overpotential of 138 mV and 247 mV respectively at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 20(g) and (h)). Self-supported catalysts could be a promising strategy as an alternative to the traditional powdery catalysts, as the polymer binders on traditional catalysts will increase the electron transfer resistance and also hinder the exposure of active sites. Self-supported catalysts show remarkable electrocatalytic performance and show high surface area. The self-supported electrocatalyst is potential in high-current-density electrocatalysis [176]. Self-supporting electrocatalysts have been fabricated through various synthesis strategies on conductive substrates such as carbon cloths, carbon papers, metal foams and plates. These substrates were chosen as they possess ample porous structure, high conductivity and specific surface area. For example, Sivanantham et al. [76] reported a cauliflower-structured rhombohedral nickel selenide (Ni3Se2) self-supported on nickel foam (NF). This electrocatalyst showed ultra-high durability with a maximum voltage loss of 5.5% even after 285 h of continuous durability test at 100 mA cm−2 (Figs. 21(a) and (b) ). The unique porous electrocatalyst increased the exposure of active sites and the strong connection between Ni3Se2 with the substrate NF due to the self-supporting feature enhanced the electrolyte activity. Endowing the electrocatalyst to afford an OER overpotential of 315 mV to attain 100 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Zhang and co-workers [177] reported self-supported 3D porous NiSe2 nanowrinkles anchored on nickel foam. The porous NiSe2 was composed of numerous nanowrinkles, which endowed the quick electrolyte supply and short ion diffusion distance (Figs. 21(c) and (d)) [178]. This porous structure furnished a large electrochemically active surface area (ECSA), which increases the active site for electrocatalytic activity, resulting in superior electrocatalytic performance. This self-supported growth of NiSe2 on Ni foam ameliorated the electrical conductivity of the catalyst as NiSe2 can grow directly onto Ni foam, which aided the electrical conductivity between them. Moreover, the assembled water electrolyzer required a low cell voltage of 1.64 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH, together with long-term stability, which maintained in 1 mol L−1 KOH for at least 80 h for overall water splitting (Figs. 21(e) and (f)). The self-supported electrodes provide a simple electrode preparation process, with a lower cost, abundant active sides and avoidance of electrocatalysts shedding these electrodes prepared by various methods have a promising application for electrocatalysis process. However, previous investigations on self-supported were mainly dedicated to OER catalysts, but the research on HER catalysts is still rare. This scarcity is attributed to the low activity of hydroxide corrosion layers for HER. Continuous efforts are required in the design of a more self-supported system for large-current-density and stable electrocatalysts. MoS2 with a layered structure similar to graphene has enhanced HER performance. Recently, self-supported MoS2 has received lots of attention due to the self-supporting characteristic that MoS2 will have a strong adhesion with the substrates, exposing more active sites, and facilitating the gas transfer and charge transfer [179,180]. The in situ growth of the MoS2 catalyst can exhibit excellent bifunctional catalytic performance for HER and OER. Li and co-workers fabricated a superhydrophilic porous MoS2/Ni3S2 grown on nickel foam (NF) via electrodeposition and solvothermal reaction [181]. Owing to its superhydrophilic and porous nature, the catalyst enhanced its capability to the water, which increased the adsorption of water molecules on its deserved sites. This catalyst exhibited good electrocatalytic performance, delivering low overpotentials of 99 and 185 mV respectively in alkaline media for HER and OER to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 22(a) and (b) ). Besides that, this catalyst displayed excellent bifunctional OWS activity with a cell voltage of 1.50 V to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The stability of this porous catalyst was also well satisfied, with a negligible increase of overpotential during the 35 h of long-term HER and OER (Fig. 22(c)). Modifying the crystal arrangement, electronic structure and chemical composition is a promising way in improving the electrocatalytic activity of the catalysts toward HER and OER. The crystal arrangement modification can increase the charge state, surface activity and conductivity. Generally, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) having the formula of MX2 can exist in several polymeric phases. Due to the magnificent physical, chemical and mechanical characteristics of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2). It has gained extensive attention [182,183]. Commonly MoS2 can be classified into three crystal phases including semiconducting 2H, metallic 1T and distorted metallic 1T’ phase. In general, the 2H phase is thermodynamically stable but as a trade-off, it is catalytically inactive due to the inert basal plane limiting its HER activity, while the 1T and 1T’ phases are highly active [184,185]. Thus, there are several methods such as lithium intercalation, chemical exfoliation or electron beam irradiation were employed to achieve phase transition from 2H to 1T or 1T’. For example, Li et al. [36] reported a cracked monolayer porous 1T MoS2 nanosheets fabricated via lithium intercalation of hydrothermal synthesis aided by ultrasonication. The predominating phase is 1T with a content of about 70%. Here, in HER activity the as-prepared catalyst showed an onset potential of –113 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Figs. 22(d) and (e) showed the overpotential of –156 mV and Tafel slope of C-1T MoS2 at 42.7 mV dec−1 respectively, which was much lower than the 2H-MoS2. The conductivity of C-1T MoS2 was higher than that of 2H MoS2, as proven by the lower semicircle in the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plot (Fig. 22(f)) [186]. The improved catalytic activity was mainly due to the abundant edge sites, open porous structure, enlarged surface area and the metallic 1T phase MoS2. The abundant edge sites and the 1T metallic phase with active basal plane increased the electrochemically active sites that can truly enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Furthermore, Yang et al. [187] synthesized the vertically arranged 1T-phase MoS2 grown on exfoliated 2H-MoS2. The unique MoS2 homostructures increased the surface area and active sites in both edges and basal planes. Here, the hierarchical nanostructures and the presence of micropores and mesopores enhanced the electrocatalytic performance. The interlayer spacing was increased due to the intercalation of oxidized solvent during the solvothermal synthesis. As a result, the 1T-2H MoS2 possessed a superior HER catalytic activity with an overpotential of 116 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1. Recently, the combination of both different structure engineering processes showed outstanding electrocatalytic activity. Our group designed a self-supported 1T/2H WS2 coupled with N-rGO on carbon cloth by the simple solvothermal process [188]. The self-supported system and phase engineered system showed significant results with a high percentage of 1T phase (57%). The catalyst exhibits a low overpotential in both acidic and alkaline electrolyte of 21.13 mV and 46.03 mV, respectively to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The porous structure of carbon cloth aided on maximizing the ECSA of the electrode substrates, uniform coating of catalyst on the substrate enables the production of more hydrogen and lower energy. The phase engineered 2D electrocatalysts with pure 1T- or 1T’-TMDC nanosheets enable researchers to understand the intrinsic optical and electrical properties. 3D printing technique which is gaining momentum in the research world in recent years has been widely adopted for electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications. 3D printing techniques may offer a simple solution in designing the electrodes, where the electrode is one of the most critical components in electrochemical applications. This technique involves the layer-by-layer deposition of material, which is based on the instruction derived from the computerized model, hence the porosity and specific architectures of the catalysts could be tailored due to the precise computer model. In 2020, Peng's group [189] fabricated graphene/carbon nanotube electrodes by extrusion-based 3D printing that owned high flexural strength and hierarchical porous structure (Figs. 23 (a) and (b)). When the electrode was integrated with the NiFeP nanosheet array (Fig. 23(c) ), the composites possessed an overpotential of 133 and 214 mV for HER and OER respectively at the current density of 30 mA cm−2 (Figs. 23(d) and (e)). Moreover, it showed good bifunctional electrocatalytic activity in the water electrolyzer with a voltage of 1.58 V at 30 mA cm−2 (Figs. 23(f)). The hierarchical porous structure offers large surface area and interconnected channels with high internal conductivity, which promotes the efficient transport of ions, electrons and gas. In short, the electrocatalytic performance could be improved by structure engineering. The electrocatalytic activity can be modified by the creation of a porous structure, creating a self-supported catalyst and controlling the type of phase. These modification strategies improved the intrinsic activities and boost the reaction kinetics. One of the advanced technologies, the 3D printing strategy was believed to produce electrodes to have geometric complexity and the design can be customized, aiming to produce the ideal electrodes for electrocatalytic activity. However, to date the upscaling and mass production of 3D printing is a significant challenge as it remains economically unviable when compare to the commercial production method. 4.2 Defect engineering Defect Engineering is one of the effective strategies to regulate the electronic and surface properties of catalysts to promote their intrinsic activities. This strategy creates more edge sites for electrocatalysis reaction and also activates the inert substrates [190]. For porous electrocatalysts, the formation of porous structures can create structural defect sites such as edges and vacancies that can tune the catalytic activity of the materials. By creating defects, it positively affects the adsorption activation energy of reactants and the dissociation energy of products in overall water splitting. Here, attention is focused on doping and vacancy creation. For instance, both of these methods can contribute to the charge imbalance near the surface, which causes the formation of active sites. Doping-induced defects have been regarded as an effective strategy to improve electrocatalytic activity. Doping can regulate the catalyst's surface and electronic structure by changing the elemental composition with the introduction of charge redistribution [1,39]. It has been widely used to modify nanomaterials which significantly improves electrocatalytic activity. This method modifies the electronic properties and the surface of the catalyst as it induces charge redistribution. Moreover, this is a constructive and controllable method to tune the electrocatalyst activity toward HER and OER. Typically, dopants can be classified into two types: metal (Fe, Ni, Co and Zr) and non-metal doping (N,P) [191–196]. The high electronegativity of nitrogen (N) enables it to activate the transition metal-based electrocatalysts. Recently, Chen et al. [197] reported the nitrogen-doped Ni3S2 on nickel foam (N-Ni3S2/NF) bifunctional electrocatalyst. The synthesized N-Ni3S2/NF exhibits excellent HER and OER activity in the alkaline solution Figs. 24(a)–(c) with an overpotential of 110 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and 0.35 V at a current density of 170 mA cm−2 respectively [197]. Furthermore, the alkaline electrolyzer requires a low potential of only 1.48 V at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 24(d) ). The nitrogen dopant enhanced the electrocatalytic activity by regulating the morphology and electronic structure of the pristine Ni3S2. Moreover, the N-Ni3S2/NF electrocatalyst showed superior stabilities for both HER and OER activities (Figs. 24(e)–(f)). This nitrogen-doped Ni3S2/NF electrode showed a high active surface area and better adsorption energy can increase the electrocatalytic activity toward HER and OER. Ding and co-workers have developed nitrogen-doped nickel-containing porous carbon networks (N-doped 3D porous Ni/C) by taking peptone as the source of carbon and NaCl as the template [194]. The synthesized catalyst possessed open-structured and porous networks that provided plenty of active sites for electrochemical reactions. Additionally, the porous network presented a short diffusion pathway, which results in low diffusion resistance and fast electrocatalyst kinetics. Notably, the catalyst N-Ni/C showed excellent HER, OER and OWS activity. Wu and his group [198] have fabricated the cobalt nanoparticles modified N-doped porous carbon spheres (CoP@NPCSs) and the synthesized materials exhibit excellent OWS activity with a low potential of 1.643 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2. The nitrogen dopant was believed to create more defects and a layered carbon structure exists in the catalyst. Besides nitrogen dopant, phosphorus (P) dopant was proved to play a vital role in enhancing catalyst activity. For example, P-doped MoS2 improved the hydrogen adsorption and release progress, as the introduction of P atoms enlarged the interlayer spacing of the MoS2 nanosheets [200]. The P dopant enhanced the intrinsic electric conductivity and generated massive active sites. The P-doped MoS2 only required a low overpotential of 43 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 in an electrolyte of 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 for HER electrocatalysis. Dong et al. [199] reported bimetallic Ni-Co phosphides hollow spheres encapsulated in P-doped reduced graphene oxide (rGO). Doping of the P atom in rGO created a unique electronic structure and enhanced the electrochemical properties for catalysis [199]. P-doping on rGO created more defects as doping caused structural distortion of rGO. Additionally, P-doping rGO formed a conductive network that facilitated electron transport. The as-prepared Ni-CoP hollow microspheres encapsulated in P-doped rGO showed enhanced electrocatalytic performance in HER and OER with an overpotential of 106 and 281.3 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 24(h)). Moreover, the Tafel slope achieved was 58.3 and 60.1 mV dec−1 for HER and OER, respectively (Figs. 24(g) and (i)). In a water electrolysis cell, the cell voltage was 1.56 V at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, by utilizing nickel foam as the substrate. In another study, Zhang's group [201] synthesized Ni-Mo bimetal aerogel (Ni-MoP) with in situ P doping. The superior 3D porous aerogel structure and the incorporation of P atoms into the Ni-Mo alloy aerogel provided an enormous amount of exposed active sites and enriched empty d orbitals to enhance the capability of adsorbing hydroxide and proton. DFT calculation indicated that after P doping, electrons were transferred to P atoms due to their higher electronegativity. The density of states (DOS) was evaluated and demonstrated that Ni-Mo-P showed better binding possibility and fast electron transfer. The P-dopant increased the electronic states at the Fermi level and enhanced binding affinities, hence increasing the electrocatalytic performance. This P-doped bimetal aerogel catalyzed HER and OER at an overpotential of 69 and 239 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, respectively. Due to the above advantages, the P-doped Ni-Mo alloy only required 1.46 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting. Concomitantly, the catalyst was highly selective with a high Faradaic efficiency of 99.8% and 99.7% during HER and OER. Metal ion doping can tailor the electronic structure and results in enhancing the intrinsic attributes. Additionally, active sites will be induced due to lattice distortion engenders and the creation of atomic defects by the doping of metal heteroatom [168,202]. Transition metals such as Fe, Co and Zr have been doped into the catalysts. Doping of heteroatoms maintains the catalyst's inherent properties and does not alter the main composition of the catalyst [203]. Among various metal dopants, the versatility of the Fe atom in regulating the electronic structure of the catalysts enables it to be extensively used as a dopant for HER and OER processes. It was verified that Fe dopant coupling with the porous structure not only modified the electronic structure of the parent structure but also provided the electrocatalysts with abundant active sites. For instance, Wang et al. [204] developed Fe-doped Ni3S2 nanoparticles in situ grown on 3D conductive Fe-Ni alloy foam (denoted as Fe-Ni3S2/AF). Notably, this is a binder-free electrode. DFT calculation was conducted to study the electronic structures and adsorption characters of Fe-doped Ni3S2 in HER. Interestingly the density of states (DOS) revealed that Fe element doping made a huge contribution in promoting the electron transfer, reducing the adsorption free energy of H*, and optimizing the ability of H2O adsorption. The optimized adsorption energy eventually increased the active sites of intrinsic activity [205]. The experimental results showed that, Fe-Ni3S2/AF exhibited superior HER and OER activity, requiring a low overpotential of 75 mV and 267 mV at 10 mA cm−2 respectively. Additionally, the active bimetallic NiFe(oxy)hydroxide in situ developed on the surface of Fe-Ni AF during OER, which promoted the mechanical adhesion and fostered charge transport between the active material and substrate. The authors compared the HER and OER performance of the Fe-Ni3S2/NF electrode with other comparable works and found that it possessed better electrocatalytic performance. When used as bifunctional electrocatalysts, the Fe-Ni3S2/AF catalyst showed small cell voltage and stable overall water splitting in alkaline media. In another paper, Chang et al. [206] presented a study on 3D hierarchical network Fe-doped NiSe nanosheets and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) grown on a carbon paper substrate. Similar to the previous work, this is a binder-free catalyst with excellent conductivity. Fe-doping modified the electronic structure and increases electroactive sites. On the contrary, a porous structure with a combination of different pore sizes produced effective channels to promote the rapid diffusion of reactants and products through the catalyst [131]. As a result, the decomposition of the microstructure during the OER process was avoided. The as-prepared catalyst showed improved electrocatalytic oxygen evolution activities with an overpotential of 282.7 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a lower Tafel slope, which is significantly better than those of the CNTs which required 362.9 mV. However, in the case of HER activity in alkaline media, the overpotential to achieve 10 mA cm−2 was 242.3 mV, which was larger than the commercial Pt/C, indicating that efforts have to be done in the future to prepare a catalyst that favors in catalyzing HER in the basic condition. Cobalt is also a potential candidate for improving the electrocatalysts’ performance, due to its moderate H-bonding energy. A proper doping level of Co2+ ions can effectively modulate the electronic structure of the catalyst and help in improving the intrinsic conductivity as well as reducing the Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) [207]. To investigate the effect of Co atoms doping on the electrocatalytic performance, a Co-doped NiO/NiFe2O4 mesoporous nanosheet array prepared via a combination of solvothermal and annealing processes was reported [208]. The researchers found that the introduction of Co doping altered the electronic structure and induced the electron transfer from Ni atoms to Co atoms. Besides, the results showed that Co-doped NiO/NiFe2O4 exhibited better electrocatalytic performances in both HER and OER processes. Experimental results showed that the catalyst exhibited 84 and 186 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER and OER, respectively (Figs. 25(a) and (b) ). A two-electrode electrolyzer was prepared and only 1.583 V was required to achieve 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH (Fig. 25(c)). Multi-metal catalysts usually exhibited better electrocatalytic performance as compared to single-metal catalysts. Similarly, with foreign metal doping on multi-metal catalysts, the adsorption energies were tuned and hence enhanced the electrocatalytic activity. As Zr is an earth-abundant element and Zr4+ showed a stable oxidation state, thus various studies on introducing Zr ion into transition metal compounds were conducted [209,210]. For example, Huang et al. [211] incorporated zirconium metal into cobalt-iron oxides nanosheets (CoFe2-O4) for overall water splitting. In this experiment, it was found that introducing Zr induced the charge transfer between Fe atoms and Zr atoms. Based on DFT calculations, Zr substitution has lowered the band gap, and subsequently, this was said to improve electrical conductivity and electron transfer as compared to pure CoFe oxides. Beyond single-element doping, anion and cation co-doping could also attain satisfying electrocatalytic performances, which is a budding strategy for gaining substantial synergistic effects. For instance, Xu and co-workers [213] demonstrated that the P and Al co-doped porous NiO nanosheets (PA-NiO) showed excellent electrocatalytic performances for HER, OER and overall water splitting processes. Results demonstrated that the PA-NiO catalyst owned better electrocatalytic performances than other samples, which exhibited 138 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER and 310 mV at 100 mA cm−2 for OER. Furthermore, the low Tafel slope confirmed that the kinetics were more enhanced on the P and Al co-doped catalyst. Additionally, when it was used as a bifunctional catalyst, a cell voltage of 1.56 V was achieved. It indicated that the anion and cation doping made a huge contribution in endowing the good performance of PA-NiO. On the other hand, Liu et al. [211] reported a Co, N and P multi-doped carbon embedded by Co2P nanoparticles, with a large specific surface area and abundant pores. The catalyst achieved an overpotential of 130 and 326 mV to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for HER and OER, in 1 mol L−1 KOH, respectively (Figs. 25(d) and (e)). As displayed in Fig. 25(f), a water splitting current density of 10 mA cm−2 was attained by applying a low cell potential of just 1.64 V. Moreover, Co2P/CoNPC possessed excellent durability for over 30000 s of operation. Although the as-reported Co2P/CoNPC displayed performance still inferior to Pt/C but it was comparable to most of the reported transition metal phosphide based electrocatalysts. The anion and cation multi-doping enhanced the electrochemical HER and OER activity, not only increasing the number of active sites and current carriers to improve the intrinsic activity but also creating a synergistic effect between multiple materials that eventually contribute to excellent catalytic activity [167,214,215]. Nevertheless, the concentrations of the dopants are important as an excessive number of heteroatoms may agglomerate and block some of the effective pores of porous electrocatalysts. In addition, the efficient mass transport and easy access of reactants to active sites were attributed to the porous structure of the catalyst. To this end, elemental doping plays a pivotal role in tuning the electronic structure of the adjacent region and also improves the intrinsic activity of electrocatalysts. The doping of different ions adjusts the available active site and electronic structure, which is essential to improve the electrocatalytic activity. Interestingly, by combining it with a porous structure, it is believed that the material functions were significantly improved, which is promising in electrocatalytic performance. Vacancy engineering in electrocatalysts has elicited growing interest in the field of electrocatalysis to escalate the inherent performance of electrocatalysts. Typically, vacancies are the point defects that have been widely investigated to modify the optical and electrical properties of electrocatalytic materials. Naturally, it is a phenomenon in crystals that occurs above absolute zero temperature, the atoms are arranged and distributed imperfectly in the crystal. Theoretical and experimental investigations have reported that the creation of vacancies can increase the density of active sites and enhance charge transfer in electrocatalysts. Hence recently, intentional vacancy creation has been created and this is known as vacancy engineering. Oxygen and sulfur vacancies in transition metal-based electrocatalysts are one of the most popular anion vacancies. The creation of oxygen and sulfur vacancies is capable in alter the electronic and physicochemical properties of the materials. Anion vacancy contributes to boosting intrinsic activity and improving the electrical conductivity of electrocatalysts. For instance, Chi et al. [212] developed oxygen vacancies enriched CoMoO4 nanosheet arrays grown on porous Ni foam (NF) supported by simple hydrothermal synthesis. The catalysts showed a low cell voltage of 1.56 V at 10 mA cm−2 towards overall water splitting when NF/H-CoMoO4//NF/H-CoMoO4 acts as both anode and cathode in an electrolyzer (Fig. 25(g)). Concurrently, the electrocatalysts were highly selective to hydrogen product with a faradaic efficiency of the electrolysis water splitting of almost 100%. The satisfying performance could be mainly indexed to the oxygen vacancies, which decreased the H2O adsorption energy onto the surface, improving the OER activity [216]. As pointed out by the authors, the oxygen vacancies endowed the as-prepared catalysts with a new defect level with higher conductivity. Meanwhile, the porous structure allowed higher interfacial contact area with higher gas diffusion and mass transport rate, which contributed to enhanced HER activity. Thereby the superior electrocatalyst performance was attributed to both the creation of oxygen vacancies and the porous structure, which brought it to a new avenue. A similar improvement can also be found in tremella-like porous Ni3S2/MnS nanosheets on nickel form with rich oxygen vacancies, which demonstrated a much lower overpotential for HER and OER of 116 and 228 mV, respectively (Figs. 25(h) and (i)) [101]. The oxygen vacancies narrowed the band gap, resulting in improved conductivity and facilitating the adsorption of H2O, while the porous structure ensured the sufficient exposure of vacancies and enhanced the mass transfer, synergistically speeding up HER and OER [217]. Apart from oxygen vacancies, sulfur vacancies are also one of the promising and widely researched vacancies. For example, Yin et al. [218] fabricated porous metallic 1T phase MoS2 nanosheets with sulfur vacancies (S-vacancies) by liquid-ammonia assisted lithiation (LAAL) route. The S-vacancies were created during the LAAL process, and with increased vacancies, more active sites were created (Fig. 26(a) ). The as-prepared porous 1T-MoS2 with rich sulfur vacancies showed an overpotential of 153 mV and a Tafel slope of 43 mV dec−1 for HER, which was low as compared to the 1T-MoS2 with an overpotential of 203 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 26(b) and (c)). In 2019, Ji et al. [219] reported a porous 1T-MoS2 with numerous sulfur vacancies was integrated with the atomic doping of Cu atoms (Fig. 26(d)). The catalyst was prepared by a simple one-pot solvothermal method and it exhibited a lower overpotential of 131 mV and Tafel slope of 51 mV dec−1 at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 26(e) and (f)). Apart from that, Zhang et al. created sulfur vacancy-rich, ultrathin porous Co3S4 nanosheets (Co3S4 PNSvac) (Fig. 26(g)). The formation of pores and vacancies was obtained by etching and reducing the function of Ar plasma [220]. The vacancies increased the intrinsic activity of active sites, while the porous structure increased the number of active sites. The abundant active sites with improved intrinsic activity can accelerate the mass transfer, thereby enhancing the catalyst HER activity. The as-prepared electrocatalyst showed boosted HER performance, recording an overpotential of 63 mV for 10 mA cm−2 with a Tafel slope of 58 mV dec−1 (Figs. 26(h) and (i)). Besides, Li et al. [221] fabricated a sulfur vacancy-rich spinel-phase Co3S4 by calcination and sulfidation-reduction strategy in an H2S atmosphere. The presence of sulfur vacancies benefitted from the H2S environment [221]. In addition, BJH proved the existence of mesoporous structure, with pore size distribution of within 2–20 nm. The existence of pore structure increased the exposed of active sites and sulfur vacancies lead to the formation of active Co3+ sites enhancing the OER performance. The overpotential for the OER process was 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with Tafel slope of 59 mV dec−1. Apart from anion vacancies, cationic vacancies are also prevalent in electrocatalysts. Cationic vacancies are capable of altering the electrocatalytic properties. For example, Ma et al. [222] also reported porous b-Mo2C spheres with Mo vacancies for improving HER activity. The creation of Mo vacancies was tuned with the HCl etching time, when the duration is too short the Mo vacancies were not able to form. For the HER process in porous b-Mo2C spheres, a low overpotential of 125 mV, low-onset overpotential of 27 mV, and high exchange current density (j 0 = 0.178 mA cm−2) with a Tafel slope of 70.95 mV dec−1 was achieved. The existence of Mo vacancies enhanced the electron transfer from the C atom to the Mo atom, involved in tuning the electron structure of molybdenum carbides, and enhanced the surface wettability. Analogously, Cheng et al. [223] also engineered NiAldP nanowall arrays with aluminum (Al) vacancies after alkali-etching. By introducing Al vacancies, the electronic structure of surface-active sites was tuned and optimized, resulting in enhanced HER and OER activities [223]. In addition, Zhang's group [224] investigated the effects of Fe vacancies on ultrathin d-FeOOH nanosheets through a wet-chemical strategy. The presence of vacancies was proven by XANES analysis, where the coordination number was reduced to 1.6. DFT results in Fig. 27(a) showed the Fe2 site (rich second neighboring Fe to Fe vacancies) possesses the optimal Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*), indicating improved HER activity. ΔG H* was one of the main parameters to determine the activity of the electrocatalyst. On the other hand, the decrease in overpotential on the Fe2 site suggested that the OER activity was enhanced (Fig. 27(b)). Notably, the ultrathin structure and unique 3D porous structure of d-FeOOH NSs/NF endowed efficient mass transfer and release bubbles from the catalyst surface. Thereby, d-FeOOH with abundant Fe vacancies coupled with the unique porous structure of the catalyst manifested superior HER and OER performances. Meanwhile, electrocatalysts with both anionic and cationic vacancies are developed to enhance the intrinsic activities of the electrocatalysts. For example, Zhang et al. [225] have synthesized a defect-rich porous monolayer NiFe-LDH (PM-LDH) (Fig. 27(c)). Based on EXAFS and ESR measurement results, it indicated the presence of oxygen vacancies and metal vacancies (Ni2+ and Fe3+) arising from its porous structure. Thus, by utilizing DFT calculations, it showed that the adsorption of H2O increased and the adsorption energy was higher as compared to the monolayer-LDH. Additionally, from the calculations, it was suggested that the Ni2+ and Fe3+ vacancies promoted OER activity (Figs. 27(d) and (e)). Consequently, the PM-LDH showed an enhanced OER performance with a low overpotential of 230 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Moreover, Lee's group [226] also demonstrated manganese dioxide (MnO2) nanosheets with both anion (oxygen) and cation (manganese) vacancies, in which these dual vacancies accelerated conductivity and enriched the active centers with optimized local electronic configuration, thereby bringing a significant enhancement on the bifunctionality towards HER and OER with a cell voltage of 1.55 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 27(f)) [226]. By DFT calculations, the vacancies were predicted to continuously induce DOS around the Fermi level endowing more defective sites for reaction intermediates (Fig. 27(g)). The synergy of dual vacancies was proven by DFT calculations, where both of the vacancies enabled the nanosheets with desired electronic structure and adsorption ability toward intermediates. The appreciable conductivity enhancement by the dual vacancies model was further verified by Mott Schottky plots and alterations of band gaps and valence band edge position (Fig. 27(h)), suggesting that MnO2 nanosheets with dual vacancies played a crucial role in exciting the charge carries to the conduction band and eventually increasing the conductivity, which considerably improved the overall water splitting. Therefore, the enhancement of bifunctional electroactivity by dual vacancies, have devoted spiraling interests to cation and anion vacancies with unprecedented functionalities, including remarkable electronic structure tuning and adsorption ability toward intermediates, as well as enriching active sites. All the works further provide insights into defect engineering and are able to highlight the rational strategies in defect engineering design for electrocatalysts in different applications. In short, these studies substantiate the distinguished role of defect engineering on electrocatalysts to improve electrochemical performance. Researchers are paving the way to produce clean energy, taking porous electrocatalysts as the stepping stones, however, the desired electrocatalytic performances are yet to be achieved. Thus, modification strategies such as defect engineering were investigated to boost the bifunctionality of porous electrocatalysts. By incorporating dopants and creating vacancies on the porous electrocatalysts, the coupling of both defects and the porous structure is an exciting advancement in the field. 4.3 Hybrid engineering Aside from defect engineering, the construction of hybrids is also an effective alternative to consolidate the electrocatalytic performance. The strong electronic interaction at interfaces and the strong synergistic interactions due to the formation of the hybrid structure serve to promote the electrical conductivity and mass transfer rate of catalysts as well as enhance the intrinsic activity, thereby improving the HER and OER activity [227,228]. In addition, the interaction between different components triggers electron redistribution and the heterogeneous interface. In this regard, creating a hybrid structure that affects the adsorption-free energy for H proton and O-containing intermediate is highly favorable for the HER and OER performance of the composite [229–231]. As illustrated by Hu et al. [232] the hybrid nanostructure could be utilized as an effective means to modify the electronic structure. The research experiment pointed out that when the Ni3S2 interlayer was added to CoMoS4 nanocolumns, the electrochemically active surface area was elevated as the interlayer suppressed the charges recombination process. Surprisingly, the as-prepared CoMoS4/Ni3S2 hybrid illustrated that the unique porous and thin-like structure of the hybrid enhanced charge separation efficiency, manifesting that the heterostructure was equipped with large surface-active sites and multi-channel. This was further affirmed by the EIS plot (Fig. 28(a) ), where the smaller arc radius of CoMoS4/Ni3S2 implied the low charge transfer resistance such that the resistance of the working electrode was well suppressed. With the superior property, this hybrid electrode exerted a cell voltage of 1.568 V to afford a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting with excellent durability (Figs. 28(b) and (c)). Likewise, Yao and co-workers [233] showcased the construction of iron and nickel phosphides hybrid on nickel foam (IP/NP-NF), which modulated the electronic structure, thereby creating a synergistic effect. The hybrid IP/NP-NF achieved the current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a small overpotential of 63 and 185 mV for HER and OER processes respectively (Figs. 28(d) and (e)). It was reported that the coupling of Ni2P and FeP enabled the charge transfer between both of the particles, creating strong synergistic effects between the two particles not only reducing the hydrogen adsorption energy but also promoting the desorption of the H from the Ni site, thereby bolstering the HER activity. On the other hand, Ni achieved a higher oxidation state due to the charge transfer from Ni to Fe species, thus resulting in an improved OER process. The ECSA increased, indicating more accessible active sites, which favored faster mass transfer. As expected, the IP/NP-NF catalyst couple required a low cell voltage of 1.567 V to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting (Fig. 28(f)). Furthermore, there is also research reported that hybrid structures affect the adsorption energy of intermediate species. Wang and co-workers [234] fabricated a CoO/Co4N heterostructure, integrated on a 3D support-nickel foam (NF) with a unique porous structure for overall water splitting. According to DFT results, the hybrid showed fast electron transport as compared to pure CoO. This fast electron transport was proven by the EIS-Nyquist plot shown in Fig. 29(a) , where the arc radius decreased as compared to Co3O4 and Co(OH)F, the lower charge transfer resistance, indicated that the fast and smooth electron migration took place in the interface. Meanwhile, the adsorption capability of CoO/Co4N was accelerated, as Co4N played the role of facilitating protons adsorption directly or indirectly from the surface of the cobalt, where when working together with the porous structure it further lowered the overpotential for HER [235]. As a result of the hybrid structure modification, the CoO/Co4N heterostructure showed a low cell voltage of 1.79 V for a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting in neutral media (Fig. 29(b)). Invigorated by the attractive properties of hybrid structures, Mai et al. [236] reported a combined hydrothermal-phosphating and electrodeposition approach for fabricating a heterostructure based on 2D bimetallic phosphide and layered double hydroxide (LDH) to construct a porous electrode assembly (Co x Mo1P/NiFe-LDH) [236]. Interestingly, no binders were needed for the fabrication of Co/MO phosphide on NiFe-LDH and NF, which ensured the mechanical adhesion without affecting the conductivity. The catalyst showed a low overpotential of 173 and 225 mV at 10 mA cm−2 towards HER and OER respectively (Figs. 29(c) and (d)), which was lower than that of a single NiFe-LDH. The coupling of Co x Mo1P and NiFe-LDH was found to have charge transfer between Ni and Fe cations, thereby resulting in strong electronic interaction between both of them demonstrating the enhanced catalytic activity, which was proved by another hybrid system [237,238]. Apart from that, the bolstered OER performance originated from the strong synergistic effect between the interfaces between Co/Mo phosphides and Ni-Fe LDH, which discouraged the activity degradation of transition metal phosphide [239,240]. Moreover, the introduction of Mo-doping on this hybrid weakens the H-bonding energy resulting in lower adsorption energy on intermediates as compared to CoP [241]. Considering the unique porous structure, it was concluded that the porous structure ensured the highly exposed surface area and massive active sites, which was beneficial for the mass and charge transfer. It was concluded that while the porous hybrid catalyst was created, the interface between different materials had strong electronic interactions and synergies, which contributed to the enhancement of HER and OER processes. Eventually, a bifunctional electrocatalyst for overall water splitting showed astounding performance with a cell voltage of 1.68 V to achieve 50 mA cm−2 was obtained (Fig. 29(e)). Notably, the outstanding stability of the catalyst was proven by a 27-h long-time test with cell voltage unchanged at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 29(f)). A similar observation was reported in Co x Mo1P/ NiFe-LDH heterostructure integrated on NF. All these studies demonstrated that the prominent activity was found to originate from the interfacial coupling, which tailored the electronic structure and increase the exposed surface area as well as available active sites. In this regard, the charge transfer between two different catalysts results in a strong synergistic effect and high inherent activity, which is beneficial for ameliorating electrocatalytic activity. Nonetheless, research has to be devoted to preparing these inexpensive hybrid electrodes to provide more insights into the long-term and large-scale synthesis of such electrocatalysts for future renewable energy applications. By the same token, it can be rationally anticipated that the dimensionality of nanostructure interfaces increases and the catalytic performances in driving HER, OER and OWS will be improved [129]. Simulated by this thought, Xiu et al. [242] reported the fabrication of three-dimensional MXene by dispersing ultrafine CoP nanocrystallites on it homogenously (CoP@3D Ti3C2 MXene). The results implied that the 3D architecture of MXene not only provided a 3D conductive network, large surface area, highly porous structure and high robustness but also limited the aggregation of MXene nanosheets (Fig. 30(a) ). Intersheet aggregation of 2D MXene nanosheets due to the Van der Waals forces of attraction and hydrogen bonding was a common problem, which minimized the accessibility and ions exchange at the electrode-electrolyte-gas triple-phase interface as well as loss of surface area hindering the full potential of MXene-based electrocatalysts [243]. As compared to pristine Ti3C2 MXene, the loss of surface area was suppressed in 3D MXene architecture, demonstrated by the BET-specific surface area analysis results of 68.5 m2 g−1 (Pristine Ti3C2 MXene) and 165.3 m2 g−1 (3D Ti3C2 MXene). Furthermore, integrating CoP nanoparticles to 3D Ti3C2 MXene to construct the hybrid structure caused an increase in active sites and reduced the reaction barrier. Based on the results, CoP@3D Ti3C2 MXene has 1.9 folds higher ECSA than CoP@Ti3C2 MXene. Meanwhile, the CoP@3D Ti3C2 MXene hybrid with the 3D interconnected network promoted the continuous charge transfer evidenced by the EIS result (Fig. 30(b)). As such, with the introduction of CoP nanoparticles to 3D Ti3C2, a dramatic improvement for OWS was anticipated, with a low cell voltage of 1.565 V to afford a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH when CoP@3D Ti3C2 MXene were loaded on carbon paper to act as the cathode and anode. On the other hand, Sun's research group reported a 3D porous CoNiO2@reduced graphene oxide nanosheet arrays on a nickel foam (NF) substrate with uniformly distributed mesopores with a diameter of 4 nm on nanosheets [244]. Ascribed by the synergistic effect of the unique heterostructure of CoNiO2 and rGO as compared to the CoNiO2 nanosheet itself, facilitated the charge diffusion, increased electrical conductivity, larger electrolyte contact area and abundant active sites. The ameliorated charge transfer of CoNiO2@rGO/NF was verified by the smallest semicircle in the low-frequency domain of the Nyquist plot and the lower binding energy of Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 peak for XPS analysis as shown in. In the meantime, the 3D conductive network, large specific surface area and porous structure endowed the hybrid with pronounced electronic conductivity, the density of surface-active sites and mass/charge transportation between electrocatalysts and electrolyte, which facilitated the electrocatalytic reaction kinetics [39]. Of note, the CoNiO2@rGO nanosheet arrays/NF catalyst required a low potential of 1.56 V at 10 mA cm−2, presenting an advanced catalyst for electrocatalytic overall water splitting. It is note worthing that, besides achieving a current density of 10 mA cm−2 researchers are aiming a higher value. Heterostructured Co3Mo nanoparticles/porous CoMoO3 nanosheets (Co3Mo/CoMoO3 NPSs) formed through thermal treatment strategies, exhibits exceptional performance in water splitting under alkaline media at high current densities, further underscoring the advantages of the creation of hybrid materials [245]. This porous heterostructure with a hierarchical flower-like microsphere morphology demonstrates an ultralow HER overpotential of 334 mV to achieve 1000 mA cm−2 (Fig. 30(c)). In terms of OER activity, a low overpotential of 410 mV was needed to drive the current density of 500 mA cm−2 (Fig. 30(d)). DFT calculations further provide insight into the mechanism for enhanced HER activity, demonstrating the charge density redistribution, consistent with the Bader charges calculation. Additionally, DFT results suggest that Co atom is the active site, as H* spontaneously moves from the Mo site to Co site (Fig. 30(e)). This outstanding performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the heterostructure and the porous design, which enhances the exposure of interfacial active sites. Notably, the hierarchical nanopores facilitate the penetration of liquid ions and the gas emission capacity, thereby further promote the catalytic activity in the gas-liquid reaction. On the whole, these studies clearly demonstrated the possible advantages of creating 3D porous hybrids, offering remarkable achievements in research and showcasing a state-of-the-art approach. They have shown that such hybrid materials can achieve high current densities at impressively low overpotentials, making the not only scientifically promising but also holding great potential for industrial applications. This research breakthrough broadens the avenue on developing and designing a promising ideal electrocatalysts for overall water splitting system. To sum up, these studies substantiated the distinguished role of creating hybrid structures as electrocatalysts relevant to HER, OER and OWS. It is concluded that the hybrid engineering by coupling different catalysts in one electrode endowed them with a large surface area, increased active sites, strong synergistic effect, strong electronic interactions and facilitated adsorption energy, which leads to significantly enhanced electrocatalytic performance. However, in order to achieve superior performance in overall water splitting, it is noteworthy to couple HER catalysts with OER catalysts in one electrode. At present, OWS processes are greatly limited by the sluggish OER kinetics, which is mainly attributed to the four-electron sluggish kinetics, hence the exquisite design of nanostructure for OER electrocatalysts is an important strategy. In view of this, more attention should be paid to designing the structure of bifunctional electrocatalysts. In addition, when a porous structure is present, the specific surface area of the catalyst increases, indicating more active sites and higher mass transfer capacity, thereby producing catalysts with better kinetic performances [104,246]. Integration of computational studies to deepen the understanding of the hybrids, according to the electronic band structure, electronic properties and the adsorption energy calculations of intermediates [247], would be a good direction for the study of hybrid-engineered electrocatalysts in the realm of electrocatalysis. This modification serves as a testament to the tremendous progress made in the field, highlighting the capacity to address crucial challenges in sustainable energy generation. 4.4 Strain engineering Strain engineering is also another effective measure to tailor the electronic structure, and adjust the d-band structure, adsorption energy and electrocatalytic performances [57]. The deformation of a solid due to the external force acting on a unit area is known as strain. Strain engineering for nanostructure is generally limited to elastic strain, which can be defined as the deformations that can recover upon stress removal, including tensile strain and compressive strain. All these elastic strain plays a role in altering the electronic structure and chemical reactivity of materials [248,249]. Li et al. [249] summarized the synthesis of strain-engineered electrocatalysts and their impacts on HER and OER. Substrate bending to introduce strain into 2D materials is one of the methods to enhance HER activity in electrocatalysts. In 2014, with the idea and concept of introducing lattice strain based on the bending of the substrate, Tan et al. [250] developed a lattice-strained MoS2 film directly grown on the curved internal surface of 3D nanoporous gold (NPG) substrate, as illustrated in Fig. 31(a) . On the curved NPG substrates, the monolayer MoS2 experienced serious bending of atomic bonds in MoS2 and out-of-plane lattice strains. The electrochemical test demonstrated an excellent electrocatalytic HER activity with an onset potential of –118 mV and Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1 (Fig. 31(b)) attributed to the bent MoS2 lattices and distortion of S-Mo-S lattice. Although the electrocatalytic performance of this method developed highly active 2D catalysts, the NPG substrate used in this study is relatively too expensive for large-scale practical applications. Hence, a large number of efforts have been paid to induce lattice strains to tune the electrocatalytic performances for a more economical design. As illustrated, Deng and co-workers proved that strain engineering was an effective strategy to enhance the intrinsic activity of transition metal compounds. In detail, Deng and co-workers [251] prepared a homogeneous NiS0.5Se0.5 nanosheets@nanorods via hydrothermal process, and the lattice strain was induced by the substrate. Typically, lattice strain was prompted by lattice mismatch, substrate-induced and heteroatom substitution [253,254]. As shown in Figs. 31(c) and (d), DFT results showed that strain plays a key role in lowering the Gibbs free energy for the HER and OER processes. Impressively, a value of t = 2.7% lattice strain favored H* adsorption kinetics, which have the lowest limiting reaction energetic barriers. In addition, the d-bandwidth decreased and the d-band center upshifted with increasing lattice strain, leading to strengthened adsorption with intermediates, thereby improving the electrocatalytic activity [255]. Consequently, the electrocatalytic activity was enhanced with lattice strain with an overpotential of 70 and 257 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 respectively for HER and OER, as well as a low cell voltage of 1.5 V to drive overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 31(e)–(g)). In another experiment, strain engineering was also used as a modification strategy to modulate the electronic structure and surface reactivity of electrocatalysts. The Ni2P/Co2P porous electrocatalysts were synthesized, and their electroactivity on overall water splitting was evaluated by Qiu's group [252] in 2020. The lattice strain was mainly due to the stacking faults in the as-prepared catalysts, applying tensile strain of Co2P crystals along [01-1], leading to the positive shift of the d-band center and strong hydrogen adsorption energy, wherein the energy barrier for hydrogen adsorption decreased. The overlapping of d-orbitals metal atoms was said to decrease the bandwidth and positively shift the d-band center energy, thereby resulting in high antibonding states than the Fermi level, leading to higher binding energy for adsorbates and easing the H2 formation [63,256,257]. According to the strain distribution calculations, the strain variations were mainly in the x-direction with an average value above 20%, where the overlapping of d-orbitals of metal atoms decreased, thereby optimizing the hydrogen adsorption free energy. After the electrochemical test for overall water splitting, Co2P/Ni2P-2%Mo showed a high bifunctionality with a cell voltage of 1.56 V in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH at 10 mA cm−2, which was comparably better than Co2P/NF prepared from MOF (Fig. 31(h)). Interestingly, Ward's group have done an ion implantation to dope strain on the lattice, creating the strain along a single axis of La0.7Sr0.3MnO3 (LSMO) film, which is epitaxially lattice-locked to a substrate. This doping method induces lattice mismatch and thus continuously manipulating the strain. This strain engineering method by doping heteroatoms with different radii is favorable for creating strain-engineered catalysts, which can be aimed to the engineering of porous electrocatalysts. Strain engineering on porous electrocatalysts is one of the rising modification methods in tailoring the surface electronic structure and the catalytic properties of nanomaterials. It was believed that the combination of strain engineering modification on porous structured catalysts could boost the electroactivity to the maximum. Notably, strain engineering is usually combined with another modification strategy such as vacancy and hybrid components, to achieve the synergistic effect in the electrocatalysts for enhancing their electrochemical performance. Nonetheless, several downsides are associated with this modification strategy. First, as mentioned above this modification route usually has to be co-created with other modification strategies, which will complex the identification of the strain-activity correlation. Next, although DFT calculations have been utilized to determine the relationship of strain effects towards the adsorption energy of intermediates, there are still challenges in the direct translation of the simulated systems of the elastic strain to experimental study. Although studies have been demonstrating the immense potential of strain engineering as an effective modification strategy in the flourishing field of electrocatalysts, limited reports have deemed the utilization of this strategy in modifying porous electrocatalysts. A summary of the electrochemical activities of various modification strategy towards HER and OER is presented in Tables 1–3 . 4.5 Advanced modifications At present, OER is still the bottleneck of overall water splitting due to its sluggish kinetics and it demands higher energy to match the reaction rate of HER. Besides the common modification methods discussed above, there are various attractive advanced modification strategies to modify the catalysts for electrochemical reactions. The typical modification method of creating heterostructure consists of materials that complement HER and OER to address the challenges of the catalysts that is effective in one of the reactions only. However, this modification method is effective if it allows preferential exposure of the active sites and establishes an electronic pathway to these active sites. Recently, amorphization of the support in single-atom catalysts (SAC) showed promising results in promoting electrokinetics. For instance, Liu et al. [258] reported on cobalt and nickel (oxy)hydroxide, which was amorphous and Ru SAC was immobilized on it (Fig. 32(a) ). The water dissociation ability was enhanced, and the electron distribution of local configuration was modulated. Subsequently, Abhisek et al. [259] successfully synthesized another amorphous MoSe2 heterostructure with Ir SAC embedded in it. The hydroxide/(oxy)hydroxide amorphous layer activation results from the conversion of selenide in the alkaline solution during SAC-Ir deposition. This catalyst showed low overpotential for both HER and OER with 89 and 200 mV, respectively to achieve an overpotential of 10 mA cm−2. The amorphous SAC has been proven to improve intrinsic activity, provide high stability, and is expected to spur new developments in a broad area of electrocatalysts. In terms of heterostructure, by creating the van der Waals heterojunctions (vdWHs) on 2D materials has recently been proved to open new avenues for fundamental scientific research and technological applications. The vdWHs are unique in tuning the electronic bandgap, bandgap alignment, coupling effect, and efficient charge transfer. For example, Tang and co-workers [260] engineered a 3D mesoporous vdWH of graphene and nitrogen-doped MoS2 via a two-step CVD process. The vdWH forms between the interface of N-MoS2 and graphene growing a 3D mesoporous structure. In the HER process, the overpotential is 243 mV to achieve an overpotential of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 32(b)). Such excellent electrocatalytic performance is attributed to the reduction and spreading of conductive charge over the basal plane, which further increases the charge transfer. In another instance, 2D COFs and carbon nanotube exhibit good performance for electrocatalytic OER, with a low overpotential of 389 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 32(c)) [261]. Hybridizing such a vdW heterostructure, successfully redistributes the charge distribution at the interface, affecting the adsorption energies of intermediates and energy barriers. Inspired by enzymatic catalysts, the active sites of heterostructure catalysts can be divided into 2 parts: catalytic sites and the microenvironment. Microenvironment is also known as specific physicochemical environment surrounding the catalytic active sites that interact with the substrates and active sites. Recently, Zhang et al. [262] regulated the microenvironment by constructing a series of pseudo-pyridine-substituted Ni(II)-porphyrins and their composites with CNTs. From the experimental results, meta-position is one of the promising positions of pseudo-pyridine N-atom to be coupled with CNTs. This position increases the electron cloud density of the metal center, which will accelerate the electron transfer from polyphrin center to CNTs. In addition, Yu and co-workers [263] involved on modulating the coordination microenvironment of metal atoms. Three N and one P heteroatoms showed the best results towards HER, OER and OWS. In alkaline HER, OER and OWS the overpotential required to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 are 38, 84 mV and 1.67 V, respectively. The auspicious results were attributed to the fact that d-band center position of Ni atoms was tuned when coordinated with other species. Both active site and coordination structures microenvironments are powerful method on modulating the porous nanoarchitectures. Modification of microenvironment offers the improvement on the geometric and electronic structures of the porous materials, which in turn determine the performances and catalytic environment. The porous structure improves mass transfer, diffusion of gas molecules and reduction of steric limitations, as well as transportation of guest species inside and outside of the structure, which lower deactivation and better turnover rates. An overview for the design of porous electrocatalysts was elucidated in Fig. 33 . 5 Potential applications and related fields Due to their distinct structure, which increase the specific surface area, accessible active sites, mass and charge transfer and resistant to activation, porous-based materials are frequently employed not only in electrocatalytic water splitting but also in various other fields, including photocatalysis, supercapacitors and electroreduction. As these applications continue to evolve, inspirations have been drawn from diverse sources. For example, Guo et al. [273] used TiO2-reduced graphene oxide (RGO) hybrids to synthesize a mesoporous film to enhance specific surface area (~260 m2 g−1). These photocatalysts were further integrated into photovoltaic cells, achieving impressive photovoltaic performance of high power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 7.58% [273]. Besides, highly efficient electrocatalysts can further serve as co-catalysts in conjunction with photocatalysts to enhance and diversify their applications. Lin et al. [274] developed introduces dual co-catalysts (NiO x and 1T MoS2) on P25 TiO2 significantly improves the photocatalytic HER activity to 1629.1 μmol h−1. This synergistic collaboration between co-catalysts and photocatalysts allows for the execution of challenging reactions that may not be efficiently achieved with photocatalysis alone. There is also increasing research on enzyme catalysis to advance electrocatalyst development. For instance, Xie's group [275] designed an efficient catalyst for both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and OER in alkaline reaction inspired by the bio-enzymatic reaction. In nature, Fe porphyric heme sites were utilized to activate and reduce O2. Researchers synthesized and modified Fe porphyrins with tethered imidazole for Fe binding as an efficient catalyst for both electrocatalytic ORR and OER process. This design approach establishes a connection between electrocatalysts development and nature through bio-imitation, utilizing the concept of the active metal centers found in NiFe or FeFe hydrogenase as catalysts for electrochemical reactions and immobilizing of enzymes on support (bio-integration) [276]. The design of these bio-inspired electrocatalysts is guided by two fundamental principles: the establishment of hierarchical transport networks to bridge length scales and the balancing of forces across different scales. To further realize the commercialization of electrocatalysts, a multifunctional ecosystem that combines photocatalysis and electrocatalysis offers a seamless and sustainable solution, catering to a wide range of applications that spans from daytime to nighttime. During the day, the ecosystem primarily operates as a photovoltaic system, with solar panels harnessing sunlight and converting it into electricity for various applications, from powering homes to running electrical devices. Simultaneously, excess energy generated can be redirected toward electrocatalytic processes such as water splitting or carbon dioxide conversion, contributing to energy storage and clean fuel production. As the sunsets and solar power generation wanes, stored energy from batteries comes into play, enabling electrocatalytic reactions to provide electricity, heat, or fuel throughout the night. Furthermore, multifunctional photocatalysis can be applied for applications like water purification and chemical synthesis during the day. This integrated ecosystem ensures a continuous and reliable energy supply, optimizes energy utilization, and minimizes environmental impact, offering a sustainable and resilient energy solution for our ever-evolving needs. 6 Conclusion and future prospects 6.1 Conclusion The engineering of highly-efficient electrocatalysts to interconvert between chemical and electrical energies plays an important role in achieving the goal of producing a renewable energy system to replace the fossil-fuel-based energy system in order to achieve sustainable development in the future. In this review, the current advancements of porous electrocatalysts for electrocatalytic applications toward energy conversion have been systematically summarized, providing insights into the intriguing design of next-generation porous electrocatalysts. First, the fundamental mechanisms of electrocatalysis with suggested measurement criteria for HER, OER and a typical water splitting system were mentioned and discussed. Moving on, various routes for fabricating porous electrocatalysts are proposed, which include hydrothermal/solvothermal, thermal decomposition, electrodeposition, wet chemical and other strategies. Interestingly, several strategies for fabricating new porous electrocatalysts have been proposed, drawing inspiration from other application. In the background of the fundamental mechanism of electrocatalysis, several modification strategies for porous electrocatalysts and their relationship to electrocatalytic performance have been spotlighted, which include (1) structure engineering (2) defect engineering (3) hybrid engineering and (4) strain engineering. The reaction mechanisms have been discussed in depth to provide a more complete understanding of the mechanisms of both half reactions occurring during the overall water splitting. As the interface reaction of HER and OER are the tri-phase (solid-liquid-gaseous) reactions, creating a porous structure can accelerate the kinetics of water splitting. Upon taking account of the engrossing features of porous structured electrocatalysts, such as large specific surface areas and abundant electrocatalytic active sites, facilitating the mass transport and transfer of electrolytes, sufficient contacting space and penetration of electrolyte in the catalysts, various porous electrocatalysts have been ingeniously devised for versatile applications in electrocatalysis, namely HER, OER and OWS. Although significant progress has been achieved, there are still several challenges that remained and needed to be tackled in order to realize the practical applications of porous electrocatalysts in the realm of electrocatalysis on commercializing it. 6.2 Future prospects and science challenges Firstly, from the synthesis point of view, porous electrocatalysts still face some limitations. Although multifarious fabrication strategies have been reported, the hydrothermal/solvothermal method is currently one of the most widely accepted approaches to synthesizing electrocatalysts with various porous morphology, low cost and convenience. Nonetheless, these methods are not economically feasible for commercializing as there will be a large amount of loss, where not all the electrocatalyst adheres to the substrate. To further improve the hydrothermal synthesis, microwave-assisted hydrothermal is a better alternative due to their uniform heating, lesser energy consumptions, reduce synthesis time and higher yield. As another typical means for preparing porous electrocatalysts, the thermal decomposition method mainly utilizes high temperature and high energy consumption, which tends to increase production costs. On the other hand, the electrochemical deposition method deposited the nanomaterials on different substrates without using any binders, but the morphology is difficult to be tuned restraining the wide application of this strategy. Besides, despite the vast potential of the wet chemical strategy in constructing nanomaterials with high efficiency and low cost, the process alone is difficult in producing high-quality porous structures. As for other preparation methods such as the CVD approach, ball milling approach and ALD are simple. However, the limitations of each of the processes such as harsh condition in CVD, time-consuming and higher energy consumption of ball milling process and the high cost of laboratory ALD instruments and precursors often restricts the exploration in these strategies [277–279]. Each method has its own characteristics, combining several synthesis strategies to overcome one's weakness by acquiring another's strengths could be one of the effective techniques to produce electrocatalysts with improving electrocatalytic performance. Secondly, with the development of the porous structure that substantially affects the properties of electrocatalysts, concerted efforts should have been devoted to facilitating the mass transfer and creating abundant active sites. Considering the porous structure and pore size distribution, the synthetic method with desirable porous structures and densities is one of the limitations in creating optimum-performance porous electrocatalysts. Typically, three distinct categories of porous materials exist, namely micro-porous, meso-porous, and macro-porous materials. These various porous materials come with differing reaction conditions, whereby, meso-porous materials have the highest reactivity. However, previous studies have indicated that the resulting pores are often disordered, hence the precise control of the porosity remained a great challenge. Given this, it is imperative to direct extensive research efforts toward the development of suitable synthesis and modification techniques aimed at producing electrocatalysts with manageable and scalable pore size and distribution, leading to optimizing electrocatalytic performance. Considering the stability of porous nanoarchitecture electrocatalysts, much effort has been dedicated to obtaining functionalized porous electrocatalysts with high activity and satisfactory stability. However, there are still some limitations where most of the bifunctional catalysts are designed for alkaline environments, and only a few are in acidic/neutral medium. The strong corrosive nature of the acidic medium will lead to a decline in the stability of catalysts, while in the neutral medium more energy is needed to overcome the sluggish kinetics of OER. Therefore, more efforts should be focused on fabricating porous electrocatalysts that can be strongly stable in pH universal water-splitting. For example, coating the porous electrocatalysts with graphite carbon can improve the catalysts’ conductivity and stability [280]. Another proposed method is by doping the suitable element to adjust the coordination configuration to control the electronic structure of the active sites. Additionally, at elevated current densities, catalyst degradation due to corrosion is a prevalent problem. This occurs particularly when certain sites within the catalyst material lack a crystalline structure, making them susceptible to water or ion attack. Adjusting the geometric arrangement presents an alternative approach to enhance the electrocatalyst's resistance to corrosion. Furthermore, electrochemical water splitting is a multi-step reaction, especially for OER, which has a complicated electron transfer process. To develop a bifunctional electrocatalyst, practically it is essential to develop a two-electrode configuration to ensure that both HER and OER half reactions could be catalyzed effectively. However, most HER catalysts perform better in acidic media, while OER catalysts perform better in alkaline conditions. Therefore, it is hardly illustrating the efficient activity of OER in acidic media, due to the dynamical transformations of the structure and phase on the surface of these catalysts during the OER process. Thus, many modification strategies have been employed to prepare porous materials to boost the reaction kinetics and it is crucial to develop efficient HER catalysts in alkaline media to achieve electrocatalytic water splitting. Among them, more attention should be paid to strain engineering to extend the promising catalysts for OER or bifunctional catalysts for overall water splitting. The strain-engineered electrocatalysts have a strong adsorption strength of O intermediates, which minimize the energy barrier of the OER, thereby increasing the OER activity [281]. Considering that the structural characteristics of porous electrocatalysts mainly depend upon the fabrication strategies and conditions, coupling theoretical simulation and various in situ and operando characterization techniques is essential to explore the structure and active sites of catalysts to provide clear elucidation of the structure-activity-stability relationship. In addition, it is very important in understanding the actual mechanisms and kinetics of the electrocatalytic system, which will provide fundamental knowledge in the advancement and design of hybrid components. In view of this, to provide a precise underlying mechanism analysis several advanced characterization techniques including X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), in situ XPS measurement and in situ Raman spectroscopy have been developed to provide insights into the atomistic level and pore structure-property relations. Furthermore, coupling the advanced characterization techniques with computational simulation via DFT calculation is also important to decipher the correlation of the electronic structures, interfacial charge dynamics, intermediate energy binding and electrocatalytic activities. More theory calculations combining novel Machine Learning and Material Genome should be widely applied to design the new porous structure with high electrocatalytic activity in universal pH electrolyte.
