The synergy between theoretical and experimental results with the aid of other advanced technologies such as machine learning, big data, digitalization and artificial intelligence (AI) can help to automate various electrocatalyst designs. Thus, gaining insights into the electrocatalytic mechanism and in-depth analysis at the atomic-scale level as well as allowing massive database modelling is beneficial for rationally guiding the design of highly optimized porous electrocatalysts in the future. Moreover, life cycle assessment (LCA) holds great promise in shaping electrocatalysis as it is closely intertwined with the techno-economic aspect [282,283]. LCA helps identify opportunities for cost reduction, resources optimization and sustainable innovation throughout the entire lifecycle, ultimately advancing more environmentally and economically viable solutions and allowing the technology to achieve higher levels of readiness. It is worth highlighting that to compare the performance of electrocatalysts from the different research groups, a standardized measurement is necessary to be developed. The use of different mass loadings of catalysts, catalyst supports, methods to prepare working electrodes and different reaction conditions will somehow affect the accuracy of comparing the performance of various materials. For example, the stability of porous/electrocatalysts is always one of the main evaluation criteria in fabricating a high-performance catalyst. Currently, the stability evaluation index is not consistent, here a general index of stability evaluation of 10 h in future studies is suggested. A standardized evaluation index will not only be beneficial for comparison, screening and optimizing the materials from the existing system, but also helpful in evaluating the newly developed system. To further commercialize porous nanoarchitecture catalysts, effective integration into electrolyzer system is essential. The optimization of the interface between catalyst and the electrolyte is a challenging step to ensure efficient water splitting. Looking ahead, there are some of the forefronts of research in sustainable electrocatalytic water splitting offer exciting directions with the potential to revolutionize clean energy production. Some of the appealing directions of exploration include the design of advanced catalysts, exploring the concept of tandem electrocatalysts, refining the design of porous electrocatalysts and tailoring the porosity with specific porosity features, such as hierarchical or bimodal porosity. Moreover, innovative porous materials such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent-organic frameworks (COFs), and other emerging materials with enhanced catalytic performance and stability. In the future, electrocatalysts with exceptional stability have the potential to be in challenging environments, including high temperature, low temperature, a wide pH range and seawater conditions. Investigating the active sites, mechanisms, and geometric properties allows for the anticipation of vulnerable to degradation during reactions. This, in turn, can significantly prolong the operational lifespan of electrocatalysts. Additionally, the establishment of a multifunctional ecosystem that integrates both photocatalysis and electrocatalysis provides a cohesive and sustainable solution that caters to a diverse range of applications, extending its functionality from day to night seamlessly. In summary, porous structured catalysts as one of the promising classes of electrocatalysts in the realm of electrocatalysis have been exhibiting promising performance for overall water splitting. Up to now, magnificent progress has been achieved in the fabrication of porous materials, however, the current porous electrocatalysts are yet to attain satisfactory performance. On the account of that, more research should be conducted to design and construct porous materials, with desired structure and composition which is robust, low cost, high activity and selectivity for overall water splitting. Meanwhile, in line with the industrial revolution 4.0 (IR 4.0), 3D printing is aimed to be a new strategy to prepare porous materials with tuneable morphology according to the needs of the application with high precision and it is highly scalable and ready for commercialized application. Last but not least, in the pursuit of safeguarding the environment, the recovery of catalysts represents a compelling research avenue. Some of the nanomaterials such as sulfides-, silver-, cadmium-, indium-based and other environmentally unfriendly materials, attention should be paid to reduce the environmental pollution. To mitigate the environmental impact, it is crucial to focus on the active development of processes of catalysts recovery and the desorption of catalytic materials. It is believed that with further understanding of the reaction mechanisms and the aid of advanced characterization techniques, the aforementioned bottleneck and challenges can be undoubtedly surmounted, serving as an effective approach to realize the transition from lab-scale trials into real-world large-scale water electrolysis in years to come (Fig. 34 ). Ong, ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng., 2023, 11, 5547–5558. Wee-Jun Ong received his B.Eng. and Ph.D. in chemical engineering from Monash University. He is a Professor and Assistant Dean in School of Energy and Chemical Engineering at Xiamen University Malaysia. Starting from 2021, he serves as the Director of Center of Excellence for NaNo Energy & Catalysis Technology (CONNECT). Previously, he was a scientist at Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR), Singapore. In 2019, he was a visiting scientist at Technische Universität Dresden and a visiting professor at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. His research interests include nanomaterials for energy storage devices, photocatalytic, photoelectrocatalytic, and electrochemical H2O splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation. For more details, refer to https://sites.google.com/site/wjongresearch/.

coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical overall water splitting (OWS) has drawn much research fascination as a promising technology for energy conversion to produce clean hydrogen fuel as sustainable chemical resources. However, half reaction of the water splitting reaction, which is oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the main challenge due to the sluggish kinetics and large thermodynamic barrier. Porous-based materials can markedly enhance the accessibility of active sites, increase specific surface area and optimize the adsorption/desorption of reactants. The enhanced activity arising from the porous materials is attributed to the increase in active sites and improved mass transfer. Herein, the recent research advances made in porous electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and OWS are reviewed. This review focuses on the recent advancements in the synthesis strategies, incorporated with the unique roles of porous structure in electrocatalysts are discussed. For boosting the activity, various emerging modification strategies on porous electrocatalysts, covering structure engineering, phase engineering, defect engineering and strain engineering are presented. This review emphasizes on the synthesis methods, how porous materials improve the performance, mechanistic understanding, integrated experiments, theoretical studies in water splitting, advanced modification strategies and proposed synthesis processes. Specially, the structural-activity relationship gives insights into designing and modifying the porous-based materials with unique properties. Finally, the current science challenges and direction for the future development of porous electrocatalysts are highlighted.
